Hurricane Ian was one of the most powerful storms ever to hit the U.S., making landfall on Florida‚Äôs Gulf Coast on September 28. Ian‚Äôs 150 mph winds and heavy rains knocked out power for 2.6 million residents and caused $12.6 billion in insured losses, although the total damage it wrought was much more than a simple number value can demonstrate. From a weather perspective, the storm also brought widespread flooding across the state, and with that water, a strange visitor!  The floodwaters of Ian carried some unexpected visitors across the state of Florida: animals that were displaced from their natural habitats by the storm surge. One of them was a shark that was trapped in someone‚Äôs backyard!  Storm surge can sometimes bring sharks and fish in from the ocean into places they don‚Äôt belong. ¬©Bill Harrison from Wellington, New Zealand, CC BY 2.0 , via Wikimedia Commons ‚Äì License 51,262 People Couldn't Ace This Quiz Think You Can? Take Our Brand New A-Z-Animals Sharks Quiz  A viral video (check it out below) shows the shocking moment when a news anchor covers a clip from Florida in the wake of Hurricane Ian. The clip shows a shark swimming around in a pool that used to be a lawn, clearly out of place and confused. The shark is estimated to be a juvenile but still large enough to cause alarm. Nobody wants to see a shark in their yard, especially if they don‚Äôt even live on the coast!  The news anchor narrates the scene with disbelief as the camera zooms in on the shark‚Äôs fin as it flips around in the shallow water, clearly confused as to where it is or how it ended up there. Unfortunately, the clip ends before we see what happens to the shark.  The video has sparked a lot of reactions online, with some people expressing sympathy for the shark and others wondering how they would react if they found a shark in their backyard.  How Animals Are Impacted by Natural Disasters  Experts say that sharks can sometimes end up in flooded areas after hurricanes as they follow fish that are swept inland by the storm surge. They also say that sharks are unlikely to attack humans unless provoked or threatened. That being said, it‚Äôs important to be aware of the current conditions, for example, don‚Äôt go swimming in storm surge after a storm (for a lot of reasons).  However, they advise people to stay away from flooded areas and avoid contact with any wildlife that may have been displaced by the storm. They also urge people to report any sightings of sharks or other animals to local authorities, who can help relocate them safely.  Check Out the Clip Below!  Up Next:

It took 20 months, but Clifton's Fire Station 1, damaged by floodwater from the remnants of Hurricane Ida in early September 2021, returned to action on Friday.  The station, at First Street and Madison Avenue, was among the many area buildings damaged by the storm's heavy rain and floods.  Mayor Ray Grabowski said the station's reopening is particularly welcomed by the nearby residents of the city's Dutch Hill section, which it serves.  "It should mean faster response times," he said.  City Manager Nick Villano said the work included replacing damaged walls and raising heating and air conditioning units above the flood line. Villano said the foot-high water that passed through the station was enough to shut the building for almost two years.  The station's kitchen, bathrooms, roof and offices were upgraded, Villano said. When asked how much was spent, he deferred to the deputy fire chief, who was not available for comment.  Councilman Tony Latona said the time it took to complete the repairs was unconscionably long.  "This is long overdue," he said. "We should have gotten this open, because it is a life-safety issue."  The city maintains a budget surplus for emergencies such as these and should have used it to get the station reopened immediately, instead of waiting for insurance money and/or FEMA funding, said Latona, a retired city firefighter. He said the city rebuilt the station in a piecemeal fashion.  A number of factors contributed to the time it took to get the station reopened. City officials said there was a wait for insurance funds, repair plans to be drawn up and the relocation of utilities, including the water heater, from the basement to a higher level where future floods won't touch them.  There was a need for a second round of bids in 2022. In the first round, the city rejected the sole bid of almost $700,000 for the work. A second bid came in last summer at $400,000, which the city accepted. Officials said the process slowed the progress.  Before the station's reopening, its engine was temporarily housed at Station 3, which is several blocks away across Main Avenue, or stored at Station 6 on Broad Street when temperatures fell below freezing.  More:Feeling healthy? It could be because a study says NJ is 10th-healthiest state  Work on the project is not yet complete. The city is in the midst of replacing the concrete apron in front of the station.  Fire Chief Frank Prezioso said that in the coming days, a new apron reinforced with rebar will be poured and will be 10 inches thick to accommodate the weight of the firetrucks. The work is expected to take three weeks to cure.  Currently, the engine is parked on the street or in a nearby lot owned by a neighbor who has agreed to let the truck park there.  Ultimately the city hopes to close both Stations 1 and 3 and replace them with a new station. In the past, the city has looked at building a new fire station on Getty Avenue that can respond to both sections in a timely manner.  Negotiations for a site have fallen through, and the city is trying to work out a deal for another site.

The Climate Prediction Center (CPC) continues the El Nino WATCH in their latest monthly update. Above avg. sea surface temps. have spread a little more westward near & along the Pacific equator, & it continues to be readily apparent that a full fledged El Nino will be unfolding in the coming months.  Virtually all forecast models are in the same ‚Äúcamp‚Äù but to varying degrees, of course. It‚Äôs worth noting: (1) spring ENSO forecast are notoriously difficult [though a developing El Nino does seem well on its way & does make sense after 3 straight year of La Nina.... (2) the implications of an El Nino seem less reliable now possibly due to the unusually warm ocean waters around the world.  An El Nino‚Äôs global impacts have a tendency to be felt strongest in the late fall through winter into early spring. But an El Nino does potentially have significant implications for the hurricane season. The Atlantic Basin has a tendency to have a lower number of tropical cyclones due to an overall increase in mid & upper level shear - the enemy of tropical systems. The Central & E. Pacific, on the other hand, often has an above avg. season of tropical cyclones. But remember it only takes one hurricane in the wrong place at the wrong time to cause great harm.  Considering our global ocean temps. are the warmest on record of at least the satellite era, a burgeoning El Nino may equate to even warmer water temps.  The Jaguars football schedule for 2023 has been announced. The avg. high temp. for each home & away game:  Jacksonville University has launched a ‚ÄúClimate Innovation Challenge‚Äù with ‚Äúseed funding‚Äù that will range from $1,500 to $10,000. The info. is * here * but the ‚Äúnuts & bolts‚Äù:  Story continues  ‚ÄúDuring this ‚ÄúShark Tank‚Äù style grant competition, students, faculty and staff, and members of the Northeast Florida community are invited to present their climate problem-solving or awareness proposals for the opportunity to win funding.  This grant competition is interdisciplinary and welcomes participants from the arts, humanities, sciences, medical and health services, engineering, business, military offices, law, public policy, and government.  Proposals will be due on July 21, 2023, and notification of acceptance will be sent on September 1, 2023. If you are chosen to move forward to the semi-finals, you will be invited to present to an expert panel in a public forum. We will welcome creative presentations including, but not limited to, innovative demos, PowerPoint presentations, mock-ups, and prototypes.  Prize money might be used, for example, but not limited to, developing a play, documentary, a needed research project, a legislative or regulatory proposal, an invention, a new business, civil education program, or a community project.‚Äù  ‚ÄúWater Reuse Week‚Äù from May 14 - 20th...  Breakdown for Duval Co.:  St. Johns Co.:  Clay Co.:  Nassau Co.:  Putnam Co.:  St. Johns River Water Management District:  ‚ÄúFlorida has long been recognized for its use of reclaimed water, and as our state‚Äôs population continues to grow, it will become increasingly important to find alternative water sources,‚Äù said St. Johns River Water Management District Executive Director Mike Register. ‚ÄúRecognizing Water Reuse Week is an excellent opportunity to raise awareness of the District‚Äôs efforts to implement innovative management strategies to conserve water for future generations.‚Äù  Florida water utilities began using reclaimed water in the 1970s and it has quickly become a major component of water resource management by local governments and utilities within Florida and the District. There are currently 140 facilities that provide reclaimed water throughout the District. As of 2021, those facilities produced 391 million gallons per day of reclaimed water flow, of which 223 million gallons per day was used for beneficial purposes throughout the region.  Water reuse is the process of taking what was once wastewater, treating and disinfecting it, then using the resulting high-quality reclaimed water for a beneficial purpose, such as golf course and landscape irrigation, groundwater recharge and industrial uses. Extensive treatment and disinfection ensure that public health and environmental quality are protected.  The District actively promotes and encourages efficient and effective use of reclaimed water by:  Implementing a cooperative funding program that provides financial assistance to entities developing alternative water supplies, including water reuse  Funding studies and pilot programs that promote innovative treatment technologies and  Engaging in innovative uses and applications of reclaimed water  More info. * here *.

Marika and Stefan Weiss are back to living their dream.  The couple reopened Peter‚Äôs German Ice Cream & Coffee Shop in a new downtown Fort Myers location on Monday, May 15.  ‚ÄúIt already is like home to us,‚Äù Marika said of their charming spot on Dean Street, which was once home to Green Cup Cafe. ‚ÄúWe did a lot of remodeling work. It flooded after the hurricane. We repainted and made minor changes. It‚Äôs cute.‚Äù  On Pine Island:New restaurant: Owner of hurricane-closed Olde Fish House is back with new venture  The Weisses originally opened their popular shop on Hendry Street in August 2021 but had to vacate in January after other plans for the space were made.  They found the Dean Street location in early February.  ‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt have imagined being closed for five months,‚Äù said Marika. ‚ÄúIt took a lot of time for everything.‚Äù  The couple came to the United States from Germany in April 2021 with one goal in mind.  ‚ÄúWe came to work,‚Äù Marika said. ‚ÄúStefan always wanted to have an ice cream shop in Florida. He loves warm weather and ice cream. He told me when we met (in 2013) that he wanted to move to Florida one day. After COVID we said, ‚ÄòLet‚Äôs go. If we don‚Äôt do it now, we never will.‚Äô‚Äù  All-natural ice cream for you and your pup  Ice cream in the U.S. is different than what they were used to.  ‚ÄúFor us, American ice cream is very sweet,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWe wanted to bring our love of food to Americans. We only use natural ingredients in everything we do. There are no artificial ingredients.‚Äù  Stefan makes 15 flavors of ice cream, with hazelnut, After Eight (mint chocolate) and mango, ‚ÄúMade from real mangoes,‚Äù the most popular.  There‚Äôs also an extra special flavor.  Restaurant news:Fort Myers Beach restaurant swept away by Hurricane Ian reopens in new location  ‚ÄúWe have dog ice cream,‚Äù Marika said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs liverwurst and honey. You can eat it if you really want but it‚Äôs not really good for our taste. Dogs love it. They can eat in the courtyard.‚Äù  The outdoor area is something their last location didn‚Äôt have.  ‚ÄúThe courtyard is beautiful,‚Äù Marika said. ‚ÄúIt is very cozy. We love it.‚Äù  Best-selling bakery, breakfast, lunch items  Returning customers will notice the familiar too.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a little smaller space but customers won‚Äôt see it,‚Äù Marika said. ‚ÄúIt looks like before inside. The furniture is pretty much in the same place. And we didn‚Äôt change the menu so everything is the same.‚Äù  Besides Stefan‚Äôs ice cream, you‚Äôll find breakfast, lunch and bakery items and coffee on that menu.  Apple cake, plum cake and cheesecake are best sellers ‚Äï all made with traditional German recipes.  ‚ÄúWe had a lot of regulars come every day,‚Äù Marika said. ‚ÄúOffices ordered breakfast and lunch. The butter croissant with cheddar, bacon, tomato and egg is popular. The German roll, too, with liverwurst and cheese. At the moment, our bread comes directly from Germany. We plan to make it in the future.‚Äù  'Local and very good' coffee  Peter‚Äôs originally opened in the spot occupied by Java House.  ‚ÄúWe kept their coffee,‚Äù Marika said. ‚ÄúWe tried it and it tasted wonderful. It‚Äôs local and very good.‚Äù  She singled out the German ice coffee ‚Äï vanilla ice cream, coffee and whipped cream ‚Äï as another of the shop‚Äôs best sellers.  If you hadn‚Äôt tried Peter‚Äôs before, now‚Äôs your chance.  And Marika hopes you do.  ‚ÄúI would love to see all my customers and regulars,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAnd I would love to meet new ones in the new shop. There are such friendly people here. Everyone speaks to you. That‚Äôs not common in Germany. I think this is a better location with more people walking by. We will be happy here. That is the best wish I have.‚Äù  Note: The ice cream maker was not working when they opened Monday, May 15, so no ice cream was available. They hope to have it fixed in the next few days. Until then, the shop will close at 5 p.m. instead of 9 p.m. Call (239) 400-5282 for updates.  Peter‚Äôs German Ice Cream & Coffee Shop, 1412 Dean St., Fort Myers; open 7:30 a.m. to 9 p.m. Monday to Saturday (see above note); (239) 400-5282; peters-icecream.com; follow on Facebook  Robyn George is a food and dining writer for The Fort Myers News-Press. Send scoops and news to rhgeorge@gannett.com.

The public can expect an improvement in the communication coming from the Barbados Meteorological Services (BMS) as the 2023 hurricane season nears.  This was the promise made by Senior Meteorologist Semelka Jackman, during a BMS‚Äô Media and Communications Workshop for media practitioners, at their Charnocks, Christ Church main offices on Monday.  Along with better communication, providing transparency will also be high on the agenda for the BMS.  Jackman told Barbados TODAY that in spite of some select cases of misleading weather information being circulated around social media by some citizens, the Barbadian public has been extremely supportive and receptive of the work being conducted by service.  She said the BMS is committed to delivering timely and relevant information through the Government Information Services and other media partners. The office hopes that this transparency helps to stamp out the circulation of fake news.  ‚ÄúWhat we realised is that if we don‚Äôt speak to the public, they don‚Äôt have anyone to listen to, so then they will just listen to anyone. If we continue to be in their faces, share what is happening, give them updates when something is coming,  ‚Äúthen the public receives it well‚Ä¶ They do trust the brand that the BMS has, but we just have to make sure that we are out there.‚Äù  Monday‚Äôs workshop was used to update media houses on Impact-based forecasting ‚Äì weather forecasting that includes examining the vulnerability of people and property to weather conditions and warnings of the associated impacts.  Jackman noted that given the experiences of the BMS with past whether systems, including the ‚Äòfreak storm‚Äô which hit the island in June of 2021 and Hurricane Elsa in July of 2021, the first hurricane to hit Barbados since 1955, the service understood fully the importance of keeping communication channels open at all times in order to keep Barbadians well informed about heightened weather conditions.  The official noted that a number of redundant systems are in place between BMS and the Department of Emergency Management (DEM).  ‚ÄúWe have a lot of backups when it comes to communicating, so in a case where something is developing, we want to make sure we can communicate with DEM if nobody else, which is why there are different avenues to communicate.  ‚ÄúIn a worst case scenario where Barbados cannot communicate outside of the island, as it relates to meteorological aspects, then there are different countries that take over monitoring. So there are regional backup plans.‚Äù  Meanwhile, Jackman said Barbados should be on the lookout for any storm-like systems that develop off the African coast, given the level of climate change that has been seen for some time.  ‚ÄúBecause of climate change, you see more and more of those spikes of more extreme weather. Yes, there will always be tropical storms and hurricanes, but then you might start to see the increase in those Irma‚Äôs and Maria‚Äôs {hurricanes]. That does not mean that Barbados will get hit by Irma, but it means that generally you would see more droughts happening, more peaks in those cases of extreme rainfall and high rainfall totals.‚Äù  (SB)  Read our ePaper. Fast. Factual. Free.  Sign up and stay up to date with Barbados' FREE latest news.

Sarasota Herald-Tribune  Development, costs may drive out Floridians  Everyone in the United States ‚Äì let alone the whole world ‚Äì cannot live in Florida. And yet, building departments throughout the state keep rubber-stamping permits for developers to develop every inch of land for condos, subdivisions and whatever else will win approval.  We constantly witness the devastation of this state from hurricanes. Since buildings are crowded together to maximize the number of units a builder can put up in an area, it‚Äôs no wonder that when a hurricane hits, there‚Äôs so much damage.  And you wonder why our homeowners insurance is skyrocketing?  Some companies are requiring flood insurance even if you don‚Äôt live in a flood zone. How will builders even sell these new homes, especially if a mortgage is needed to finance it? Mortgage companies require insurance.  More:How to send a letter to the editor  More and more insurance companies are pulling out of Florida. We can‚Äôt have one company (Citizens) covering everyone. This is not rocket science.  It will get to a point where it is no longer feasible to live here. We will become ‚ÄúFlorifornia.‚Äù  Marsha Oldinski, Englewood  JFCS provides valuable mental health care  JFCS agrees, in part, with the opinions expressed in a letter May 10 regarding access to mental health care (‚ÄúAffordable mental health care not available‚Äù). JFCS believes this issue needs real solutions that break down barriers to accessing mental health care.  The causes of access issues to mental health care are many. They include inadequate funding and low reimbursement rates, workforce shortages, higher out-of-pocket cost for care and stigma.  These issues are not new, but still are significant challenges in accessing care.  I want to take a minute to respond to the writer‚Äôs statement that ‚ÄúAgencies that used to offer help, like JFCS, don‚Äôt anymore ‚Ä¶‚Äù  JFCS provides mental health care to some of the most vulnerable citizens living in our community, at no cost, such as kids who are living with addiction in the family or who have had a brush with the law.  In addition, 25% use our financial assistance waiver program and only pay an average of $15. We extend our gratitude to foundations and donors whose philanthropic dollars typically support these services.  We are so appreciative to have their generosity.  JFCS does help, and we help a lot. Do we agree we need better access to mental health care for all? You bet!  Dr. Helene Lotman, president and CEO, JFCS  Heading toward dystopian wild, Wild West  I‚Äôm not invisible but wish I could be. That way, I could walk into any movie theater, grocery store, nightclub, house of worship, mall or concert hall without feeling like I‚Äôm in a sniper‚Äôs crosshairs.  At 77 years young, I‚Äôd like to live out my final years in wrinkled bliss, but I feel like I‚Äôm sitting in a rocking chair with no rockers.  Today we have ‚Äúconcealed carry,‚Äù tomorrow ‚Äúopen carry‚Äù complete with 10-gallon hat, ammo belt with fast-draw holster, cowboy boots and spurs.  I hate to cut this short, but as soon as I put on my bulletproof vest, I‚Äôm headed to the furniture store to get some new rockers for my rocking chair. Hope I make it, pardner.  William Upton, Sarasota  Don‚Äôt cut down Australian pines  Australian pines were widely planted as barriers and screens in the late 1800s in Florida. It has now been learned that their shallow root systems and heavy leaf debris overwhelm native plants. They are deemed invasive.  But keep in mind some salient points:  Hurricane Ian, in September 2022, destroyed many, many trees and understory plants.  The Gulf Coast is in a big drought now with the storm season fast approaching.  Heavy rains on barren or nearly barren land spell big erosion.  A tree, even a supposedly ‚Äúinvasive‚Äù one, is still a tree and better than nothing.  In other words, leave well enough alone. Don‚Äôt clear-cut!  Bureaucrats in the Venice area are on their high horse and have targeted in at least two instances the few remaining trees because they are Australian pines.  Replant native trees as soon as possible but use common sense in the meantime. We‚Äôre in trouble.  Joan Farrell, Venice  Possible corruption in Sarasota? Shocking  I was shocked to read May 12 that someone may have tried to influence our local officials by donating money to a local foundation (‚ÄúImproper influence claims plague project‚Äù). I wonder if anything like this has ever happened before in Sarasota.  More:Condo on hold as police investigate report of job offer to planning board member  It appears the controversy involves the $500 million downtown project known as One Park Sarasota and the timing of these donations. I think it‚Äôs very sad that this could be happening in this beautiful town I grew up in.  Thank goodness something like this could never happen in Washington, D.C.  Tom Allman, Sarasota  Question of the Week  The Opinion page invites readers to tackle our "Online Question of the Week."  Ready? Here it is:  If you were throwing a dream dinner party and could invite one prominent local or state figure to attend as a guest, who would it be ‚Äì and why?  Here‚Äôs some guidance on your answers: Feel free to be funny, clever and/or imaginative, but please, let‚Äôs not be mean.  Email your responses by Thursday, May 18, to editor.letters@heraldtribune.com.  We will publish the best responses Saturday, May 20, at https://www.heraldtribune.com.

Environmental and community groups sued FEMA and the Department of Homeland Security last month over two grid projects, accusing them of violating the National Environmental Policy Act by failing to consider environmental harms that resulted in the rebuilding of ‚Äúoutdated, inefficient, and centralized fossil fuel-based electricity infrastructure.‚Äù  Congress allocated about $14 billion to federal agencies including FEMA and the Department of Housing and Urban Development for Puerto Rico to address the unprecedented destruction caused by Hurricane Maria in 2017 when it roared ashore, killing almost 3,000 people and triggering blackouts that lasted nearly a year. Last September, Hurricane Fiona left thousands of residents without power for 12 days and caused intermittent outages for many others.  Climate advocates want FEMA to spend those billions on rooftop solar, storage and other forms of distributed renewable energy for communities at risk of losing power ‚Äî rather than the centralized power system that was largely wiped out in 2017.  Augusta Wilson, a senior attorney at the Center for Biological Diversity, one of the organizations involved in the lawsuit, said FEMA is on the cusp of spending billions of dollars on permanent work to rebuild Puerto Rico‚Äôs ‚Äúhighly unreliable‚Äù electricity grid, rather than investing in resilient projects as a viable alternative, which it ‚Äújust hasn‚Äôt considered as part of its NEPA analysis.‚Äù  ‚ÄúFEMA‚Äôs current plans really fly in the face of the will of the people of Puerto Rico,‚Äù Wilson said.  A FEMA spokesperson declined to comment, citing a policy against speaking about active litigation. But the agency has allocated $11.4 billion to Puerto Rico‚Äôs government-owned utility, including the largest single allocation in FEMA‚Äôs history of about $9.4 billion in emergency spending after Maria to restore damaged substations, buildings, distribution lines and transmission system. As of April 20, FEMA has approved about 120 projects under the program, representing about $1.5 billion.  Jenniffer Gonz√°lez-Col√≥n, Puerto Rico‚Äôs representative in Congress, acknowledged the complexity of dealing with multi-agency processes, coordinating participants and responsibly handling such a large pot of money. ‚ÄúBut the reality is the people do not see it is happening fast enough,‚Äù she said.  But she also said the reconstruction of Puerto Rico‚Äôs transmission and distribution system should be a priority to stabilize the network in the near term before long-term plans can be implemented.  ‚ÄúForcing agencies to go to court before work can continue only delays these processes even further, and does not provide electricity to any home or any industrial plant and puts a risk to the funding,‚Äù Gonz√°lez-Col√≥n said.  Development of renewable energy projects has ramped up since Fiona, but Puerto Rico is well off the pace to reach its legally binding target of 100 percent by renewables by 2050, as well as its near-term target of 40 percent by 2025, with clean energy generation still in single digits.  ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs not making [hitting the renewable target] possible is the political will,‚Äù said Federico Cintr√≥n Moscoso, director of El Puente Puerto Rico, another of the organizations suing FEMA.  DOE also has $1 billion available under a separate pot of funding Congress allocated for Puerto Rico in the omnibus bill last year. Six Democrats urged Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm in an April letter shared with POLITICO to ensure DOE spends the money specifically on solar and storage. The DOE closed a request for information on potential projects on April 21 and expects the first awards to be announced this fall. It also plans to issue a request for proposals on deploying solar and storage for single-family homes.  Rep. Darren Soto (D-Fla.), one of the letter signees, said the group wants to make sure the money gets out the door in the right way and feels the DOE is ‚Äúmoving at a steady clip.‚Äù  One of the main reasons the Energy Department was tagged to implement the $1 billion program was because lawmakers and people in Puerto Rico wanted to avoid working with agencies associated with years-long delays in distributing funding under recovery and modernization efforts, according to the letter.  But one Congressional aide noted the letter was sent partly because of concerns from people in Puerto Rico about how Gov. Pierluisi was positioning his agencies to control the money flow ‚Äî and whether they could effectively distribute the funds that are intended to provide solar power and battery storage to households with individuals with disabilities and low-income households.  ‚ÄúIt would be hard to underestimate how problematic it would be if any of that [$1 billion] money was used to prop up fossil fuels,‚Äù the aide said.  FEMA has the ultimate decision over which projects should be supported, Wilson said. But climate advocates say the agency‚Äôs rebuilding mindset has yet to implement the Biden administration‚Äôs efforts to address the pollution that takes a disproportionate toll on communities of color, low-income areas and rural residents.  With Biden‚Äôs Earth Day order on environmental justice and his administration‚Äôs Justice40 initiative, which aims to steer 40 percent of federal benefits to communities that face the heaviest burdens from pollution, there is ‚Äúa lot of public policy coming out that you would think there would be a reversal of how things are managed in FEMA, but that doesn‚Äôt seem to be the case in Puerto Rico,‚Äù said Laura Beatriz Arroyo, a senior attorney with Earthjustice, which is also involved in the FEMA litigation.  FEMA does have at least one big fan: Gov. Pierluisi. In an interview with POLITICO in March, he praised the agency‚Äôs response to Fiona and ‚Äúthe breathing room‚Äù FEMA has provided in helping protect the territory from future hurricanes by providing additional generation to supplement Puerto Rico‚Äôs power plants. Thanks in part to FEMA‚Äôs efforts, he said, ‚Äúour grid has become more resilient.‚Äù  But he‚Äôs drawn pushback from solar energy advocates for his administration‚Äôs plan to spend $100 million in federal funds for a program that would finance up to 30 percent of the costs for middle-class homeowners to install solar and battery systems.  That effort, the governor‚Äôs office said, is ‚Äúintended to ensure that all sectors have access to solar systems.‚Äù And more than $400 million, the vast majority of HUD‚Äôs Community Development Block Grant funding available for these incentives, will go to low-income families, which will also be prioritized in the DOE program, according to the statement.  Another $800 million in HUD money will fund development of community microgrids serving low- and moderate-income households throughout the territory, it said.  Solar industry players warn the proposal is having a ‚Äúchilling effect‚Äù on installations because people who can afford the systems are canceling orders and waiting for the incentives for those with higher incomes to kick in. This echoes complaints often levied at these types of incentive programs on the mainland that they end up benefiting more affluent households than those most in need of government support.  One solar company executive called it a ‚Äúreverse Robin Hood,‚Äù taking money that should be funding systems for the poorest residents in a territory where the median household income is just shy of $22,000. The new income threshold would make ‚Äúeveryone except for Bad Bunny‚Äù ‚Äî the popular Puerto Rican singer and activist ‚Äî eligible for the incentive, said the executive, speaking anonymously because of competitive and sensitive relationships with government officials.  A National Renewable Energy Laboratory study last year identified 203,000 ‚Äúsolar suitable‚Äù households in Puerto Rico in the very low-income category. In non-metro areas such as the municipality of Salinas, which was devastated when Hurricane Fiona dropped 32 inches of rain, a very low-income household is tagged as a family of four that makes about $12,300.  ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs not enough money to go around for that [lower] income category so there‚Äôs very little sense for going off that bracket,‚Äù said Javier R√∫a-Jovet, chief policy officer of the Solar + Energy Storage Association of Puerto Rico.  Charles Venator-Santiago, associate professor in the University of Connecticut‚Äôs Department of Political Science and El Instituto: Institute for Latina/o, Caribbean and Latin American Studies, noted Pierluisi is running for reelection next year ‚Äî and said it ‚Äúwouldn‚Äôt surprise me if some middle-income residents are selected to receive these funds‚Äù for political reasons.  Cintr√≥n Moscoso said the governor and local agencies are obstacles to the territory‚Äôs renewable energy transition, controlling the flow of the money with limited transparency and public participation.  ‚ÄúRight now, I don‚Äôt see anyone in the government that is fighting for renewable energy in a very serious way ‚Ä¶ and that is very worrisome.‚Äù

Thirty percent of Americans live along the coast ‚Äî and it‚Äôs easy to understand why. Proximity to the beach, ocean vibes, sunsets that seem filtered and a less pressure-cooked atmosphere contribute to the allure. But this flocking to the shore comes with risk and potential costs.  As Americans concentrate homes and businesses along the coasts, we concentrate the insurance risk in those areas vulnerable to sea-level rise, flooding and super storms. In no state is this more apparent right now than Florida, where more than a dozen insurance companies have cut their losses and moved out of the state, concentrating the already concentrated risk on even fewer companies.  The storms are expensive to the insurance companies, but it‚Äôs homeowners who pay the ultimate cost.  Massive payouts due to natural disasters like Hurricane Ian have left Floridians paying on average $4,200 per year for homeowners insurance. This is compared to the $1,500 average for the rest of the country. Floridians are left with fewer options, more expensive premiums and gut-wrenchingly small payouts that don‚Äôt begin to cover the cost of damages wrought by Hurricane Ian, the costliest storm to hit the state and second-most costly to hit the U.S. after Hurricane Katrina.  Many Floridians have had to switch to the state-run company, Citizens Property Insurance Corp., an entity created in 2002 as an insurer of last resort for those who couldn‚Äôt find coverage in the private market. Their policies have more than doubled in the last two years and now account for 13% of the state market.  Just in case the reader doubts the connection between insurance premiums and climate change, note that insurance companies are pricing in the risk. Their actuaries apparently all agree that climate change poses significant risk.  If they didn‚Äôt, perhaps a climate-change-disputing insurance company could cut their premiums and thereby pick up a whole lot of business in Florida. No company is pursuing that strategy. It‚Äôs pretty solid proof that the insurance industry is convinced that climate change is real.  The numbers make the case. Privately insured losses in Florida due to Hurricane Ian are estimated at $46-67 billion. Federal flood insurance claims have mounted to $10 billion. Of course, these insurance payouts have come only after homeowners have fulfilled their deductibles. And a new hurricane season is about to start.  It‚Äôs easy to highlight the problem, less easy to solve it. We can harden infrastructure and prepare for storms. Most logically, we should also reduce the risk of future sea level by innovating away from the fuels that cause warming. After all, rises in sea level are compounding the hurricane losses.  Another nearer-term solution: Make some sites uninsurable. Build a McMansion on a barrier island if you like, but don‚Äôt expect it to be insurable. If you lose it; you lose it. This would make insurance more affordable for people building more modest homes in less disaster-prone locations.  We‚Äôve taken out ‚Äúinsurance policies‚Äù on environmental risks in the past, and those policies have paid off. In 1985, a junior scientist noticed something peculiar. Jonathan Shanklin was a researcher at British Antarctic Survey when he found what he first thought was an anomaly; inputting a backlog of data, he discovered that the ozone layer, which he presumed would be the same year after year, had started thinning. He shared his findings with the scientific community, who raised the alarms. Something urgent and effective needed to be done globally about ozone-depleting substances.  That‚Äôs when two conservative leaders shined. U.K. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and President Ronald Reagan decided to act. Prime Minister Thatcher was a research chemist. President Reagan had been persuaded by his secretary of state, the late George Shultz, that it made sense to ‚Äúbuy an insurance policy‚Äù against the risk posed by the ozone hole.  Shultz told Reagan that it wasn‚Äôt 100% certain, but that there was clearly a risk. That risk, Shultz said, need an insurance policy. The result was the Montreal Protocol, the popular and effective international treaty, ratified in 1987, that continues to this day to repair the ozone hole.  It‚Äôs too late to buy fire insurance when your house is on fire or when a hurricane is bearing down. It‚Äôs not too late, though, to address climate change and to tame the forces that are creating the more expensive storms. That‚Äôs an environmental policy that would ultimately have an impact on Floridian‚Äôs insurance policies.  Former U.S. Rep. Bob Inglis (R-South Carolina, 1993-1999 and 2005-2011) is the executive director of republicEn.org, a community of conservatives who care about climate change. Inglis will be speaking May 17 to the Rotary Club of Hialeah-Miami Springs and May 18 to the Rotary Club of Coral Gables. This opinion piece was originally published by The Invading Sea.

Canadiens fans will probably keep wondering for years to come what might have been if the team had selected Brady Tkachuk instead of Jesperi Kotkaniemi with the No. 3 pick at the 2018 NHL Draft.  Tkachuk has played 359 games with the Ottawa Senators since they took him with the No. 4 pick and he has 125-150-275 totals to lead all players from that year‚Äôs draft in both goals and points. The rugged, 6-foot-4, 211-pound left-winger also leads all players from that draft in penalty minutes with 493 and is now captain of the Senators.  The 23-year-old Tkachuk would have been a perfect linemate for Canadiens captain Nick Suzuki, 23, and Cole Caufield, 22, for the foreseeable future.  Meanwhile, life in Carolina has been pretty good for Kotkaniemi since the Hurricanes acquired him from the Canadiens with an offer sheet during the summer of 2021. As compensation, the Canadiens received a first-round pick at the 2022 NHL Draft, which they then traded to the Arizona Coyotes along with a second-round pick in 2024 in exchange for Christian Dvorak.  While the Canadiens and Senators both missed the playoffs this season, Kotkaniemi and the Hurricanes are in the Eastern Conference final with Game 1 against the Florida Panthers slated for Thursday in Carolina (8 p.m., CBC, SN, TVA Sports).  Kotkaniemi, 22, played all 82 games with the Hurricanes this season, posting 18-25-43 totals and a plus-10 differential while averaging 14:44 of ice time and winning 51.4 per cent of his faceoffs. In the last 22 regular-season games, he had 7-11-18 totals. In 11 playoff games, Kotkaniemi has 3-3-6 totals and it was his shot on a power play that teammate Jesper Fast deflected in for a 3-2 OT win over the New Jersey Devils in Game 5 for the Hurricanes to clinch their second-round series.  The Hurricanes paid a big price to get Kotkaniemi, offering him a one-year offer sheet worth US$6.1 million after he had scored only five goals and added 15 assists in 56 games the previous season with the Canadiens. After being made a healthy scratch for Game 5 of the 2021 Stanley Cup final ‚Äî which the Lightning won 1-0 to clinch the championship ‚Äî Kotkaniemi was probably looking for a road out of Montreal and the Hurricanes were willing to pave one for him.  The $20 signing bonus that came with the Hurricanes‚Äô offer sheet to Kotkaniemi was an obvious shot at former Canadiens GM Marc Bergevin for the five-year, US$42.27-million offer sheet he gave Hurricanes centre Sebastian Aho ‚Äî who wears No. 20 ‚Äî during the summer of 2019. Hurricanes billionaire owner Tom Dundon was willing to match the offer that had US$38.62 million in signing-bonus money, including US$20 million in the first 12 months.  Aho, 25, had 36-31-67 totals in 75 games this season and has 5-5-10 totals in 11 playoff games.  Hurricanes GM Don Waddell insists the offer sheet for Kotkaniemi wasn‚Äôt payback for Aho, noting he had tried unsuccessfully to make a trade with the Canadiens to get Kotkaniemi before making the offer sheet. The Hurricanes now have the No. 2 (Andrei Svechnikov) and No. 3 picks from the 2018 draft and they also have former Canadiens captain Max Pacioretty after acquiring him from the Vegas Golden Knights last summer.  The Hurricanes have advanced to the conference final without having Svechnikov or Pacioretty in the lineup. Svechnikov tore the ACL in his right knee during a game in March and Pacioretty tore the Achilles tendon on his right leg for the second time in January. Pacioretty suffered the same injury during training last summer and after returning to the lineup he scored three goals in five games before tearing his Achilles again.  ‚ÄúIt certainly was not revenge,‚Äù Waddell said about acquiring Kotkaniemi. ‚ÄúWe talked about this player, we know this player. We had an opportunity to use the CBA as other teams have in the past to try to acquire a 21-year-old player. To us it was all about the player. We looked around the league and thought this made the most sense from where we are as a team. As you know, we have a couple of other good Finnish players on our team and thought this would be a great fit.‚Äù  Kotkaniemi is now looking like a very good fit with the Hurricanes, who have him locked up through the 2029-30 season with an eight-year, US$38.560-million contract that has an annual salary-cap hit of $4.82 million. Hurricanes head coach Rod Brind‚ÄôAmour said Kotkaniemi has impressed him with his two-way play, adding he still has room to grow and that he is just ‚Äúscratching the surface.‚Äù  One has to wonder if things might have been different for Kotkaniemi‚Äôs development in Montreal if he had Martin St. Louis as head coach instead of Claude Julien and Dominique Ducharme.  After Kotkaniemi scored the winning goal in a 4-3 shootout victory over the Canadiens at the Bell Centre on March 7 , I asked him if he ever wonders what it might have been like to play for St. Louis.  ‚ÄúNot for a second,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm happy where I am right now. I really love my life in Raleigh. I love this group. We have a great group of guys and everything is working out really well so far.‚Äù  [email protected]  twitter.com/StuCowan1  Related  Copyright Postmedia Network Inc., 2023

Climate change adaptations are going on all around South Florida to prepare for and fight back against sea-level rise. While they‚Äôre important and necessary, there may come a day in the not-too-distant future when they stop working because the ocean will keep rising and eventually, it becomes too expensive to keep adapting over and over.  That brings us to a very complicated and controversial climate change solution, but one that most climate scientists feel is inevitable: managed retreat.  We know that chaotic retreat happens after big disasters like Hurricane Irma, but managed retreat is trying to get out ahead of the problem.  "We are going to lose land to climate change impacts, whether its sea level rise where the land just goes underwater, to flood plains that expand as a result of rain bombs dropping so much water at once," said Alice Hill, who worked in the Obama administration and is an expert on managed retreat.  Get South Florida local news, weather forecasts and entertainment stories to your inbox. Sign up for NBC South Florida newsletters.  A.R. Siders, an assistant professor at the University of Delaware, has been researching managed retreat for years.  ‚ÄúThe general principles behind a managed retreat, what would make it different from chaotic retreat, are really having agency over the choice, so making it feel like people who are retreating making it feel like this is a choice for them," Siders said.  Retreat may seem like something in the distant future, but as University of Miami professor Katharine Mach told NBC6, it‚Äôs already happening.  ‚ÄúWe look to the Netherlands as one of the greatest examples of feats of engineering to manage water and river systems from rainfall, low-lying agricultural areas, but in these processes, where there's been a lot of engineering, there also has been a real emphasis on making room for the river," Mach said. "So restoring the banks of a river, such that when it floods, natural flood plains can help absorb that water."  New Orleans is one of the most vulnerable cities on the planet when it comes to sea level rise, but it's actually the unprotected bayous south of the Crescent City that are disappearing at a shocking rate. Isle De Jean Charles, once home to 300 families, has shrunk by 98% since 1995 because of the rising Gulf Of Mexico.  In 2016, the Louisiana Office of Community Development won a $48 million grant to relocate the residents 40 miles north to a brand new town with brand new homes and brand new infrastructure, appropriately called The New Isle.  Building 100 new homes is certainly a good start, but what about the thousands of other people living in Louisiana right now that will be underwater in the coming years?  Managed retreat is happening much closer to home in the Florida Keys. In parts 4 and 5 of our 5-part series, we‚Äôll take a look at why the Keys are so vulnerable to sea-level rise, show how adaptations and retreat are both happening right now and ultimately ask the question: Is it too late to save the Florida Keys?

DeMarco Morgan is co-anchor of ‚ÄúGMA: What You Need to Know‚Äù and an ABC News correspondent filing reports for all ABC News programs and platforms, including ‚ÄúGood Morning America‚Äù and ‚ÄúWorld News Tonight with David Muir.‚Äù  Prior to ABC News, DeMarco Morgan was co-anchor of KCBS weekday morning‚Äôs 4:30-7:00 a.m. and 11:00 a.m. newscasts in Los Angeles where he also reported for all CBS News network broadcasts and platforms, notably anchoring national and local evening newscasts for the CBS Evening Weekend News and WCBS television station soon after the CBS Broadcast Center halted its operations due to the COVID-19 outbreak. Before that, he was a CBS News correspondent. In August 2017, he field-anchored the network‚Äôs coverage of Hurricane Harvey live from Houston for ‚ÄúThe CBS Evening News.‚Äù Shortly thereafter, he reported live from the field on the devastation caused by Hurricanes Irma and Florence.  Morgan has covered stories ranging from destructive wildfires in California to the deadly Las Vegas Mass shooting that left dozens of concertgoers dead when a gunman opened fire on the crowd attending the Route 91 Harvest music festival. He also filed live reports for nearly all CBS News platforms, from both the RNC and DNC 2016 political conventions, the funeral of Aretha Franklin, and the Pulse nightclub shooting.  Prior to that, Morgan worked at WXIA-TV in Atlanta, where he spent three years as a reporter and co-anchor of the station‚Äôs 5, 6 and 11 p.m. weekday newscasts. Before that, Morgan worked as a weekend evening anchor for WNBC-TV in New York while also serving as a cut-in anchor for MSNBC, worked as a weekday evening anchor and reporter at WTVJ-TV in Miami, WISN-TV in Milwaukee and WJTV-TV in Jackson, Mississippi.  When he was not on the air, Morgan taught broadcast writing and reporting to students at Morehouse College, Spelman College and Clark Atlanta University. He also taught broadcast journalism at his alma mater ‚Äì Jackson State University.  Morgan graduated from Jackson State University, where he received a Bachelor of Science in liberal arts. He also earned a master‚Äôs degree in journalism from Columbia University.

In the early hours of February 6, two large earthquakes hit southeast T√ºrkiye. Tremors and aftershocks were felt in Syria and the region. Just two weeks later, another earthquake struck southern T√ºrkiye. These earthquakes have claimed nearly 60,000 lives and caused untold destruction to homes and infrastructure.  One hundred days later, the full scale of the devastation from the earthquakes is still being uncovered. Many people living in the earthquake zones who had previously lost their homes because of the Syrian conflict must now rebuild completely, a process which could take years.  In the immediate aftermath of the earthquakes, Airbnb.org (a US-based nonprofit) stepped up to offer assistance and financial support to UNHCR teams in T√ºrkiye to help book short-term accommodation for refugees displaced by the disaster.  To talk about this partnership ‚Äî and more broadly about the work Airbnb.org is doing to help those displaced find temporary housing ‚Äî we spoke with Moli Dow, the Response and Partnerships Manager for Europe, the Middle East and Africa at Airbnb.org.  USA for UNHCR: Moli, could you tell us how Airbnb first became involved in providing temporary housing for people that have been forced to flee their homes?  Moli Dow: Sure. It all started in 2012 after New York was hit by Hurricane Sandy. An Airbnb Host in Brooklyn named Shell contacted Airbnb and asked if she could offer her place for free to people who had to evacuate. The Airbnb team thought it was an amazing idea and worked long hours to make it an option for other Hosts as well. After that, over 1,000 Hosts made their homes free for evacuees. Since then, Airbnb founded Airbnb.org, an independent nonprofit organization that responds to humanitarian crises as well as other natural disasters. We've provided support for wildfire evacuees in Australia, hurricane evacuees in the Americas, asylum seekers across Latin America, frontline workers during the pandemic, more than 20,000 refugees from Afghanistan in 2021, and nearly 130,000 refugees fleeing Ukraine since the start of the conflict. So far, we have helped well over 250,000 people find temporary housing through these programs.  USA for UNHCR: When and why did you start working with USA for UNHCR?  Moli Dow: UNHCR has been a longtime collaborator with Airbnb and now Airbnb.org. In 2016, Airbnb launched a donation campaign to raise funds for UNHCR, matching contributions from the Airbnb community and helping to raise over $1.6 million to support refugees globally. We have always valued UNHCR teams‚Äô willingness to share key intelligence and guidance about housing needs on the ground, as well as your expertise in providing disaster relief and temporary housing. Our partnership is rooted in collaboration and information sharing.  Over the past couple of years, our teams have been discussing how our organizations can further optimize our work together, including exploring how USA for UNHCR could utilize Airbnb.org to expand housing support. This meant we were already set up to respond when the earthquakes in T√ºrkiye struck.  USA for UNHCR: Great segue! Could you talk a bit about your response to the crisis in T√ºrkiye and Syria?  Moli Dow: As I mentioned, both sides were prepped and ready to discuss how we could work together to respond to this crisis so we could mobilize quickly, which was great. I think one of the main reasons Airbnb.org wanted to support USA for UNHCR, particularly for this crisis, was because your work aligned so well with our diversity, equity, inclusion and accessibility commitments. Following the earthquakes, we've been supporting both local and refugee populations with many coming from vulnerable, marginalized backgrounds. We wanted to make sure we partnered with international, national and local organizations that share our commitment to equity and are proactively focusing on these populations to supplement the government‚Äôs efforts. This is a key reason Airbnb.org provided a grant to USA for UNHCR to fund short term accommodation for refugees.  USA for UNHCR: What‚Äôs next for Airbnb.org?  Moli Dow: Right now, we‚Äôre working to improve accessibility alongside diversity, equity, and inclusion in all that we do, embedding equity centered-design methods into our work and our organization. This includes partnering with more community-based organizations and nonprofits that share our commitment to equity, like USA for UNHCR, as well as working with leading diversity and equity experts to help assess and improve our work.  We‚Äôre really excited to continue to learn and grow from our partnerships, particularly our partnership with you. The earthquake response in T√ºrkiye is the first time our teams will be directly working together to support housing for refugees, and we anticipate many opportunities to expand this collaboration, including our work focused on supporting asylum seekers in other parts of the world.  USA for UNHCR: What advice would you have for other organizations that are considering supporting refugees, whether it‚Äôs working directly with USA for UNHCR or other partner organizations?  Moli Dow: Internationally, refugee resettlement schemes are at a really important inflection point. In this climate, Airbnb.org is prioritizing finding and working with organizations ‚Äì like UNHCR ‚Äì who are embracing new models, programs and innovations to meet rising needs. Equally, we think it's paramount that organizations work with partners who put the safety and critical wrap-around support of refugees first.  For years, I have watched how tirelessly USA for UNHCR has advocated for refugees around the world. You expertly navigate ever changing and challenging political climates, and it's a complicated world out there!  USA for UNHCR: Finally, how can people get involved in supporting Airbnb.org's mission?  Moli Dow: People can get involved by signing up to be an Airbnb.org Host and offering their space for free or at a discount during times of crisis. They can also donate directly to Airbnb.org to support our work.  Interested in helping refugees build a better future?  Email partnerships@usaforunhcr.org to learn more about how your company, organization or foundation can partner with USA for UNHCR.

Nicholas Herboso  Meteorologist  Nicholas Herboso is the newest member of the FOX10 StormTracker Team. He comes to FOX10 from the University of South Alabama, where he studied broadcast meteorology and minored in music. At USA, he learned from a passionate faculty that inspired him to achieve high scores in his classes, earning him multiple departmental awards. This is Nicholas's first job out of college, and it is a massive achievement for him. He is excited about what his future holds at FOX10.  Nicholas is a native of Fairhope, AL, and is proud to call the Gulf Coast home. He was motivated to pursue a career in weather broadcasting after living through multiple hurricanes on the Gulf Coast and watching the coverage from local meteorologists like John Edd Thompson, especially after watching their coverage of the 2004 and 2005 hurricane seasons. Past extreme weather events got Nicholas interested in weather early on. For him, weather is a passion that he is excited to share with viewers.  Along with his passion for meteorology, Nicholas is a true music lover. His musical history goes back to his time in the J. Larry Newton School band, where he started his journey as a trombone player. He played in multiple ensembles through his schooling, culminating in his tenure as bass trombonist for the University of South Alabama Wind Ensemble. He also developed a passion for the marching arts, leading him to serve as a Drum Major for the Fairhope High School Band and the University of South Alabama Jaguar Marching Band, and outside of school with the Southern Knights Drum and Bugle Corps. Nicholas marched in both Drum Corps International and Drum Corps Associates for a total of three seasons. Two of those seasons were spent marching baritone and euphonium at Southwind Drum and Bugle Corps, a locally based corps out of Mobile.  Music has played an important part in his life, and he hopes to continue this passion outside of work by playing in local ensembles.  Outside of work and his music activities, Nicholas enjoys spending time running along Mobile Bay, shopping at local stores, and dining at local restaurants.

It‚Äôs been a few years since Brent Burns played meaningful hockey past April. The San Jose Sharks traded Burns in the summer to the Carolina Hurricanes. Carolina provides Burns with another chance to experience playoff hockey. But for Carolina and Burns, the benefits are a two-way street.  Brent Burns Providing a Boost to the Carolina Hurricanes in the Playoffs  Carolina was in need of a top-pairing offensive defenceman after failing to reach an agreement for an extension with Anthony DeAngelo this past offseason. This came after top pairing defenceman Dougie Hamilton left the year before in free agency to sign with the New Jersey Devils. Instead of signing a free agent like John Klingberg, the Hurricanes made a trade for veteran defenceman Brent Burns. And the Hurricanes got what they were looking for and more. Both in the regular season and the playoffs.  The Trip to Carolina  Almost as soon as Burns found out he was traded to Carolina, he made his way across the country to start working out with head coach Rod Brind‚ÄôAmour. While it was bittersweet to leave the Sharks, Burns was excited to join the Hurricanes and had that nervous energy again playing with a new team.  Drafted by the Minnesota Wild in the first round of the 2003 NHL Draft, Burns is a six-foot five inch, two hundred and thirty pounds offensive defenceman. Over his career, he has scored 245 goals and 593 assists and won the Norris Trophy as the league‚Äôs best defenceman in the 2016-17 season. He is known for his versatility as he started out playing both forward and defence. However, at 38 years old, his ironman ability also stands out. While he may be slightly past his prime playing ability, his relentless work ethic and top physical shape makes him a force on the ice and a top pairing defenceman.  Burns Settling in on the Top Pair  This season in Carolina, Burns stepped right in beside defensive defenceman Jaccob Slavin on the team‚Äôs top defensive pair. With Slavin‚Äôs elite defensive ability, Burns utilized his skating and offensive ability more freely. In doing so, he broke a Hurricanes record for points by a defenceman after getting 18 goals and 43 assists for 61 points in 82 games.  After Shayne Gotisbehere, Burns was second on the team in expected goals and goals scored above expected. Likewise, he was second in Corsi and Fenwick while having 2.73 expected goals against. Where Burns really stood head and shoulders above the rest though was his on-ice goal differential at 34 and on-ice expected goals differential at 43.9. He averaged 23.2 minutes per game of ice time and played in all situations. This included quarterbacking the first power play unit and killing penalties. While Hamilton was extremely productive offensively for New Jersey, Burns provided the Hurricanes with both the offence and all-around play they needed during the regular season.  Production in the Playoffs  This postseason, the Hurricanes are largely finding their strength in their team game. Jordan Martinook had an outstanding round two but no one player has consistently been carrying the team all playoffs. With that said, Brent Burns‚Äô playoffs production has been a huge boost to the Hurricanes. Carrying over from the regular season, Burns leads all Hurricanes defencemen in points and assists and is tied for the lead in goals. His goal differential is second only to Slavin. He also leads in expected goals with 1.2, expected goals percentage, expected goal differential and Fenwick. Burns‚Äô high Fenwick score is notable as it shows his unique ability to find a way to get shots through and on the net.  For all defencemen in the playoffs, Burns is in the top ten for goals, assists and points. He is fourth in expected goals and expected goal differential and top ten in Fenwick and expected goals percentage. Essentially, when it comes to defencemen generating offense in the playoffs, Burns is at the top. While Burns‚Äô offensive numbers paint one side of the picture, even his expected goals against has him in the top 20 while his goal differential puts him at fifth.  The advanced metrics show the same for the Burns Slavin pairing through 11 playoff games as they rank near the top for goals percentage, Fenwick, and xGoals % amongst defensive pairs playing at least 100 minutes this postseason. Much has been said about the impressive play of Slavin, but the addition of Burns has bumped the top pairing‚Äôs production from last postseason to this. In all of these categories mentioned above, the pairing of Slavin-Burns in 11 games has exceeded last year‚Äôs top pairing of Slavin-DeAngelo in 14 games. As much as Slavin allows Burns to play a more freewheeling game, the metrics show Burns‚Äô playoff production has benefited Slavin as well.  Burns‚Äô Off-Ice Intangibles Providing an X Factor in the Playoffs  The statistics are important to quantify most of the conclusions regarding Burns‚Äô playoff play. But to look beyond the production, Burns brings the Hurricanes a certain element that is hard to replicate. Burns is a colorful character. He is a giant defenceman with a large beard, tatoos and some missing teeth. His backpack is always ready to go with an assortment of random items. But more notably he always has a smile on his face. He seems to love life and that shows in his game play.  At 38 years old, he is a mentor to not only the younger players, but most of the team. Leading by example by being a workhorse in the gym and on the ice, age is just a number to Burns. He also consistently has teammates over for barbeques and has acclimated to life in Raleigh as his kid plays youth hockey with Brind‚ÄôAmour‚Äôs and ex-Hurricane Justin Williams‚Äò kids.  These intangibles are character traits that you cannot quantify in a trade value. But they are just as, if not more, important than how many goals he can score. For a team with high playoff expectations but significant injuries, it takes more than a stat sheet to overcome that adversity. The Hurricanes team game has shined in the playoffs so far but that does not happen without players like Burns providing some glue. Brind‚ÄôAmour has repeatedly stated how fantastic Burns has been this year. Not only as a player but as a person.  Burns on the Ice is Exciting as Off the Ice  Meanwhile, watching Burns on the ice is also a treat. To start with his skating, he is deceptively good to be so large. Defensively he uses his big frame and large reach to break players off the puck. He is not afraid to use his size to push players around and throw some hits. Many times, he is skating backwards with a forward quickly approaching. It looks the forward is about to beat him, but he somehow turns around to break up the play.  Then take a look at Burns running the point in the offensive zone. He walks the blueline as well as almost any defenceman right now not named Cale Makar. He then finds an opening to boom his monster shot through, either finding the back of the net or getting a tip or rebound. But let‚Äôs say not much is happening from the point. Then you see Burns turn on the jets and put his hands in motion. The six foot five defenceman dangles his way to the net and drives in to slide the puck into the net or make a play. Burns creates significant challenges for other teams to analyze how to handle him.  Brent Burns Versatility a Game Changer for Carolina  As the stats and narrative show, Burns is not simply a one-dimensional player. While he is more offensive in nature, he is good in all three zones. Burns can produce on the power play and kill penalties. He can break up a play and move the puck quickly in transition. He can score from the point and deke his way past the goalie. The Hurricanes only gave up forward Steven Lorentz, goalie prospect Eetu Makiniemi, and a third-round pick in the 2023 NHL Draft to receive Burns. San Jose also retained part of his salary in that trade. This has been a home run acquisition for Carolina. The Hurricanes are a team looking to bind together and keep pushing for the Stanely Cup. Burns provides an electric, multi-dimensional player to Carolina that could be a significant piece to the puzzle missing last year.  Main Photo: James Guillory-USA TODAY Sports

Mahalo for supporting Honolulu Star-Advertiser. Enjoy this free story!  A popular snack shop in Aiea shut down Monday after 20 years of serving the community with yummy treats. Read more  A popular snack shop in Aiea shut down Monday after 20 years of serving the community with yummy treats.  Samurai Snacks Aiea LLC, at the Aiea Shopping Center, initially planned to close next week, but once the store Friday announced on Instagram its plans to close May 24, customers flocked to the store throughout the weekend and Monday for its soft-serve ice cream, freshly popped popcorn and other goodies.  A steady stream of customers lined up in front of the store at lunchtime Monday waiting to enter Samurai Snacks to purchase treats.  Walls once covered with an assortment of snacks were bare, with only a few racks left of colored puff rice, shoyu peanuts and other goodies.  The store‚Äôs display freezer was nearly empty at 12:30 p.m., with only a dozen yuzu-flavored Hawaiian Frost frozen dairy cups left. Other flavors such as chocolate haupia, lychee, honeydew melon, chocolate banana, Kona coffee and mango had sold out.  Many customers, such as 21-year-old Justin Deuz of Salt Lake, left the store carrying a cup of soft serve in their hands.  Deuz, who has been a loyal customer since he was a child, stopped by the store one last time Monday for Samurai Snacks‚Äô vanilla and strawberry swirl soft serve, a customer favorite. The store has been here for so long, and now it‚Äôs going to be gone, Deuz said.  Once all of the store‚Äôs products sold out, Samurai Snacks Aiea permanently closed at 2 p.m. Monday.  Running a small business has been tough in recent years due to the COVID-19 pandemic, said Mari Kimoto, daughter of owners Chris and Marlo Kimoto.  ‚ÄúMy mom and dad has worked really hard behind the scenes,‚Äù Mari Kimoto said.  Staff shortages, inflation, supply chain issues and minimum wage and rent increases were among the reasons that led the store owners to make the tough decision to close.  Tina Yamaki, president of the Retail Merchants of Hawaii, said small mom-and-pop businesses can‚Äôt compete with large stores and hotels that are able to pay their employees more.  ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt have national backing,‚Äù Yamaki said. ‚ÄúSo the single mom-and-pop stores, they really suffer.‚Äù  The Kimotos acquired the snack shop 20 years ago from previous owner Glenn Yamamoto.  ‚ÄúMy parents bought this when I was 1 year old,‚Äù Kimoto said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve just grown up with this business.‚Äù The Kimoto family said they are grateful for all of their customers‚Äô and vendors‚Äô support. ‚ÄúThank you from the bottom of our hearts for all the support and aloha that we‚Äôve had for the past 20 years,‚Äù Kimoto said Monday.  Samurai Snacks Aiea was the sole franchise store of Samurai Inc., a Kalihi factory on Umi Street that manufactures snack products sold at supermarkets and stores in Hawaii.  While the factory has a small walk-up window where it primarily sells soft serve and popcorn, the Aiea snack shop carried a large variety of snacks that included snacks from other vendors.  Roz Funakoshi, vice president of Samurai Inc., said, ‚ÄúSamurai Kalihi would like to say mahalo nui loa for 20 years of partnership. The people of Hawaii have lost another precious treasure.‚Äù  ‚ÄúThere are no words to express how saddened we are of their closing, but we understand it well,‚Äù Funakoshi said. ‚ÄúWe wish the Kimoto ohana the very best in their future endeavors.‚Äù

Joe Moriarity left, and Joann Moriarity, holding dog, are rescued by boat from St. Anthony of Padua Roman Catholic Church on Canal Street on Aug. 31, 2005, two days after Hurricane Katrina struck and New Orleans levees failed. Boston-based Tomorrow.io began as a software company that offered hyper-precise, street-level weather forecasting. Now it has set its sights on space.  The company recently launched Tomorrow-R1, what it claims is the world's first commercially built weather-radar satellite, via SpaceX's Falcon 9 rocket. There are very few atmospheric radars orbiting the earth currently, and all were built by government agencies. The U.S. has one, operated by NASA.  Tomorrow.io used proprietary software not just to predict but also to help companies plan for severe weather. The information it used came from government radar, data satellites, weather stations, cellular signal attenuation, and even connected vehicles with wiper and temperature sensors ‚Äî what its CEO and co-founder, Shimon Elkabetz, called the "weather of things."  The new radar satellite, however, will offer a much broader scope of data.  "We're going to create a significant revolution when it comes to weather forecasting and climate modeling and be able to help the National Hurricane Center hopefully have better hurricane forecasting and help insurance companies insure farmers in India and Brazil, and help airlines fly from JFK to London in a much safer route and by wasting less fuel," said Elkabetz.  The NASA radar satellite has a lag time of three days or more for its information, simply due to distance and how often it passes over the U.S. Local ground radar, which is what Americans usually see on the local news, is not available in all locations. In fact, most of Latin America, Africa, the Middle East, India, and many other places lack radar coverage. Moreover, land-based radar doesn't cover specific mountainous regions in the U.S., nor does it extend over the ocean. That makes it harder for coastal regions to get accurate storm predictions.  Satellites could provide coverage to billions more people.  Elkabetz said the company intends to launch more than two dozen of its own satellites over the next two years. In combination with sensor microwave technology, he says this will create a 'constellation' of weather monitoring systems that will be able to sample every point on earth, nearly every hour.  "We're putting our own designed and manufactured radar on a dedicated satellite, and we're putting many of these out there in a combination with another sensor microwave sounder that is going to put be put on another satellite," he explained. "The combination of the two together will create a global real-time precipitation map that will basically cover every point on Earth in close to real time."  Major clients now include several airlines, such as Delta , United , and JetBlue . In a case study done in 2021, JetBlue found that Tomorrow.io let it understand when a storm would stop, helping it limit unnecessary delays and cancellations, saving its operations team as much as $50,000 per month per hub.  Other clients include Fox Sports, Uber , Google Cloud, Amazon Web Services, Microsoft , and the U.S. Air Force.  Tomorrow.io has been awarded more than $20 million in U.S. Defense Department contracts and is executing a collaborative research and development agreement with National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, according to a press release.
