Welcome to 'Ask a Meteorologist,' a weekly chat that discusses a new weather topic every week.  This year, the National Hurricane Center made changes. One of those changes, instead of a five-day outlook, they will now put out a seven-day outlook.  Bay News 9 meteorologists answer your questions about what this means, as well as what we could see this hurricane season.

The Florida Panthers are in the Conference Finals for the first time in 27 years, and a large part of that has been the play of goaltender Sergei Bobrovsky. Ever since he came into the series against the Boston Bruins in relief in Game 3, he‚Äôs been a saving grace for the Panthers, backing them to a comeback series win against the Bruins, and then looking tough to beat against the Toronto Maple Leafs‚Äô superstars. He‚Äôs rocking a solid .918 save percentage in the postseason, but more impressive is his 8.62 5v5 goals saved above expected, which leads all remaining goaltenders by more than three goals.  Florida Panthers writer George Richards joined Tyler Yaremchuk and Frank Seravalli on Daily Faceoff Live to talk about how important Bobrovsky has been to this Panthers team on their surprising run, and whether or not this will continue.  George Richards: We‚Äôre going to find that out! This is the first time he‚Äôs ever been in a Conference Final as a starting goaltender. The furthest he ever got was the year that Columbus surprisingly swept Tampa Bay back in 2019, so this is as far has he‚Äôs ever come, so we‚Äôre going to find out.  Florida‚Äôs obviously playing some pretty good defense in front of him, clearing out some pucks, something that they haven‚Äôt always done, so he‚Äôs getting a little more defensive support than what he‚Äôs been used to in the past.  And he seems just like a guy that‚Äôs just in the moment. We haven‚Äôt really seen this side of Sergei Bobrovsky, it just feels a little different with him. He‚Äôs given all the praise to his teammates and talked about what a privilege it is just to be here and all that stuff, and then he goes out and he makes 45 saves, so he‚Äôs been terrific for them.  I don‚Äôt know what we can say. His 10 goals saved above expected, he‚Äôs just been great, especially in the Toronto series, and he came up clutch for Florida in the Boston series winning Game 5 with 44 saves in an elimination game for the Panthers. So, if not for Bob, the Panthers wouldn‚Äôt be here.  You can watch the full episode here‚Ä¶

The third phase of the Affordable Housing Development Fund program, which allows local governments to apply for financing for multifamily or single-family housing rehabilitation and new construction outside of the 100-year floodplain, is underway in areas that experienced major damage from Hurricanes Matthew and Florence.  The N.C. Office of Recovery and Resiliency said a total of $47 million will be awarded by fall for housing that increases community resilience to rebuild and replace some of the lost housing.  Officials added that Bladen, Duplin, Jones, Pamlico, Pender and Scotland County projects are strongly encouraged to apply for the funding.  More information and application forms can be found HERE.

Faculty Spotlight: Suzana Camargo, Plasma Physicist Turned Extreme Weather Expert  by Frederique Fyhr | May 16, 2023  Suzana Camargo‚Äôs eminent career has spanned continents and fields of study. Originally from Brazil, Camargo studied physics at the University of S√£o Paulo before venturing to Germany to earn her PhD from the Technical University of Munich and conduct research at the Max Planck Institute for Plasma Physics. After several years studying plasma physics, Camargo made the bold decision to move to New York City and join Columbia University‚Äôs International Research Institute for Climate and Society in 1999. Camargo began her work with a project on hurricanes„Éºa project she thought might last a year or so. The rest is history, she says. More than 20 years later, Camargo‚Äôs main research focus is still hurricanes.  Suzana Camargo currently teaches ‚ÄúSustainability in the Face of Natural Disasters‚Äù in the M.S. in Sustainability Science program, offered by the School of Professional Studies in partnership with the Columbia Climate School.  Did you always know you were interested in atmospheric sciences? How have your past experiences shaped your research interests?  Growing up, I always loved mathematics. Then, as a teenager I got interested in programming, which was quite novel at the time. In a family with many engineers, engineering seemed the natural pathway, but it didn‚Äôt seem a good fit for me, so I ended up studying physics. All my degrees (BSc, MSc, PhD) are in physics, which gave me a great foundation to explore many different areas. All my research starting as an undergraduate, throughout my PhD and postdoc, and until a position as an early career professor in Brazil, was in plasma physics ‚Äî in particular, turbulence in plasma physics. Thanks to that, I had expertise in fluid dynamics, programming, modeling, and turbulence. This skill set made it possible to transition to research in atmospheric sciences and climate when I started at Columbia University.  What made you transition from researching plasma physics to atmospheric sciences?  I started working at Columbia University in 1999. At that time, the International Research Institute for Climate and Society (IRI) was just starting and they gave me an opportunity to work there and start doing climate research. The transition between fields was not easy, as I had a lot to learn, whereas I was already an established scientist in plasma physics. But, it was the optimal choice for my family, given that we decided to move to the US and at the time, there were significant cuts in plasma physics, which made it impossible for me to find a position in my original field. After a year at IRI, I started working on a project on hurricanes, thinking that would be my focus for a year or so. The rest is history, as they say. More than 20 years later, my main research focus is still hurricanes. It‚Äôs a fascinating topic and I have enjoyed researching topics that are directly relevant for society.  You joined Columbia in 1999. How has your research focus changed over the years?  The first project that I led in this field was to develop a seasonal forecast for tropical cyclones (hurricanes, typhoons) using climate models. With time, I expanded my focus to work on the influence of climate on tropical cyclones on different time-scales, from subseasonal (2-4 weeks) to longer-term climate change, including even paleoclimatology. I have also been involved in studying other extreme events (e.g. precipitation), various climate phenomena, such as monsoons, and even the influence of volcanoes on climate. In the last few years, our group has been focusing on climate risk, including not only the hazards, but also taking into account social vulnerability and economic impacts.  You are an academic ambassador of the American Meteorological Society Committee for Hispanic and Latinx Advancement (CHALA) committee since 2021. Could you share a bit more about this group‚Äôs mission and your involvement?  As I am originally from Brazil, it‚Äôs important to me to be sure that Hispanic and Latinx scientists are represented and supported in the US. I also like to keep up my connections with Brazilian scientists and make sure to interact with them in conferences. Therefore, it was a natural fit to participate in the CHALA Board on Representation, Accessibility, Inclusion, and Diversity as an academic ambassador. This committee has been doing amazing work, such as helping create Spanish weather translation resources, so that the US Weather Service can issue weather advisories in English and Spanish languages easily, which is very important given the large US Spanish-speaking population. I am a co-author with some other members of the CHALA committee on the first paper analyzing the statistics on the current population of Latinx students in US academic institutions that offer programs in atmospheric sciences. There is a lot of work to be done to attract more Latinx studies to this field!  Why should students take your course? What will they take away from the course?  ‚ÄúSustainability in the Face of Natural Disasters‚Äù provides students with the foundation of many aspects of disasters, giving special focus to understanding the hazards that cause them, but also discussing other important aspects, such as disaster preparedness and response. I hope that the students will feel ready to analyze the level of risk due to different hazards that could affect them, in particular if questions arise on their job. I hope they will also feel prepared to make important decisions regarding risk in their own lives, from where they decide to live to whether they should evacuate due to the occurrence of a hurricane.

NEW ORLEANS (WVUE) - A city councilman is looking to quell fears of overdevelopment from residents of West End, as the city hopes to redevelop one of the prime pieces of real estate in New Orleans.  West End, once home to a number of famous waterfront restaurants and bars, had most of its commercial space wiped out by Hurricane Katrina in 2005.  The city has hoped to redevelop the site on the water just west of West End Park where the restaurants once sat. But public officials are sorting through a myriad of ownership issues and persistent problems slowing West End redevelopment plans.  Three years ago, officials from Jefferson and Orleans parishes formed a working group to try to move plans forward, but redevelopment remains stalled.  New Orleans City Councilman Joe Giarrusso is putting forward an amendment to change the zoning of a portion of West End, currently zoned as S-LM. The area includes the boathouses encircling West End Park and surrounding the New Orleans Yacht Harbor and New Orleans Marina, as well as the chunk of land where the restaurants once stood.  ‚ÄúResidents have expressed concern for a long time about whether or not there‚Äôs something separate going on, like some huge housing development,‚Äù Giarrusso. ‚ÄúThis meeting tonight is to tell residents that this is not the focus of the project, to eliminate all of the housing that would be here except for the boathouses, and just get feedback primarily about that.‚Äù  Giarrusso‚Äôs amendment would have to be sent to the City Planning Commission (CPC), which would then make a recommendation and send it back to the council.  If approved, it would disallow all condos, apartments and townhomes, only allowing boathouses going forward.  ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt wake up in the morning thinking about how I can build a condo high-rise, that isn‚Äôt the reason for doing that,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThis has been a place where people recreate in the past, where we had restaurants, where they really communed. I just want to make sure we‚Äôre returning that sense of New Orleans to something that‚Äôs been fallow since Katrina.‚Äù  During a meeting Tuesday night at the New Orleans Yacht Club, Giarrusso fielded questions from a number of residents about what is planned for the site.  He said, at the moment, redevelopment is stalled until the outcome of the November elections in Jefferson Parish.  Part of the land is owned by Jefferson Parish, a small sliver just north and west of the 17th Street Pumping Station.  ‚ÄúWe saw that people really do want a place to come in, enjoy a walk, be a bit more quiet,‚Äù said nearby resident Charles Marsala. ‚ÄúThis idea that it‚Äôs going to be housing, no housing, is not really long-term. Whereas if we go back to park, we can do what you do in parks: Have pickleball, have a bike path.‚Äù  See a spelling or grammar error in our story? Click Here to report it. Please include the headline.  Copyright 2023 WVUE. All rights reserved.

Florida State landed a commitment from Michigan State wide receiver transfer Keon Coleman on Wednesday. Coleman announced his decision on his birthday. The Seminoles beat out Ole Miss for Coleman's services.  He is ranked as the No. 23 overall transfer and No. 4 wide receiver in the transfer portal. He was among the top available transfers at the time of his commitment. FSU now has five commitments from transfers ranked among the 25 best available in this cycle by 247Sports.com.  Prior to making his decision, Coleman took an official visit to both the Seminoles and the Rebels. He was at FSU during the weekend of May 5th. Later that week, he made his way to Oxford to check out Ole Miss.  After his visit to FSU, he spoke exclusively with Noles247 and shared why FSU was his first stop.  "Because I wanted to see what they was about," Coleman said back on May 8th. "I wanted to give them the chance for sure because they were a place I was really looking into out of high school. Great coaches. They had a great year. And you know, they have a system with a great quarterback in Jordan Travis, and another receiver in Johnny Wilson and a lot of other key pieces. They have 88-89% of the team coming back as a whole, not just offense, but that is defense, too. So they are a complete team. I feel and they feel like they are one piece away."  After spending 48 hours around the program, Coleman was impressed.  "Great visit," Coleman said. "Straight-forward coaching . Seeing the campus. Seeing what they have to offer. Learning about the playbook, what they have offense, how they scheme things up to give me the ball and the next level to winning. They want me to help them take the program to the next level which they feel is a national championship."  FSU head coach Mike Norvell was heavily involved in the visit for Coleman.  "Just straight up guy," Coleman said of Norvell. "He let me know it's bigger than just football here, you know, it's about the community, it's about all of the things that matter, but on the field he is going to push you as hard as he can. Every single day you're going to get his best because he's trying to get the best out of you. And, you know, he also played receiver and he be with those guys, just pushing you to elevate and be great every day."  Ron Dugans, his future position coach, was also heavily involved.  "Same thing," Coleman said relating Dugans approach to Norvell's. "I mean, I gotta give him credit, he knows things on film. He watched the tape and he's done his breakdown. We had some great conversations in there."  Coleman added that they broke down his Michigan State film, as well as a 'lot of other film' including going over FSU's offense and how he could fit in.  "He was just picking my brain, bringing up defenses, seeing what you know," Coleman added.  Alex Atkins, FSU's offensive line coach and offensive coordinator, also had a one-on-one meeting with Coleman.  "Had a meeting with him too, mostly on the offense," Coleman said. "How he schemes things, his play-calling, and what he is trying to accomplish in calling those plays. Just that really."  Coleman was hosted by Johnny Wilson, a breakout wide receiver for the Seminoles who, like Coleman, was a transfer.  "I mean really just chopping it up about mostly life. Everybody knows football, so we didn't have to do too much talking about football. We know what's there to offer but he's like, we would love to have you on that other side. You are just going to make the offense unstoppable, so lets get you here."  He also communicated with FSU quarterback Jordan Travis during the visit, though the quarterback was not in town over the weekend.  "Just pretty much trying to get me here," Coleman said of Travis. "Understand that you are another big target, a guy who can do everything they ask you to do. So what quarterback wouldn't love to have that."  FSU's offense was a top-tier unit nationally during the 2022 season. Explosive plays and the ability to post points was regularly on display. It is part of the reason why Coleman was interested in the Seminoles. Why was FSU interested in adding Coleman to their offensive roster?  "We provide another mismatch on the outside, because Johnny is a big guy, so Johnny might be to the boundary but when you have another big guy you don't have to, when you are going with tempo, you don't have to always get him there. You can just put us wherever and we're gonna make a play," Coleman said. "So it's just you would have two guys beside that you don't have to worry about putting them in certain spots because they can do everything. So that's creating mismatches all over the field. We have the speed and size."  Coleman shared what stood out the most to him as he reflected on the visit.  "How transparent they were, and how intentional they were on being real and getting their point across and not trying to you know, sell the dream," Coleman said. "You are going to come here, develop, and be a better person than when you walked in here and you are also going to win."  With the addition of Coleman, the Seminoles add another top-notch wide receiver to a loaded offense. The 6-foot-4, 215-pound wide receiver, who is originally from Opelousas, La., had a breakout season as a sophomore with the Spartans. He led Michigan State in receptions (58), receiving yards (798) and touchdown catches (seven).  According to Pro Football Focus, he ranked tied for second in the Big Ten and 16th in the FBS with 12 receptions caught downfield for 20-plus yards. He also ranked second in the conference and tied for 13th in the FBS with five touchdown grabs caught downfield for 20-plus yards.  He was named a third-team All-Big Ten selection by the media and honorable mention by the coaches for his play during the 2022 season.  As a freshman in 2021, he played in 10 games and had seven receptions for 50 yards and a touchdown.  Coleman is added to a wide receiver room led by returning top receiver Johnny Wilson. Other veterans in the room include Winston Wright Jr., who will make his debut this season after missing last year due to injuries suffered in a car accident, alongside Kentron Poitier, Ja'Khi Douglas, Darion Williamson, and more. The Seminoles also have newcomers such as Destyn Hill, Vandrevius Jacobs, and Hykeem Williams.

Following Hurricane Ike, Chrishelle Palay was inspired to pursue a career in housing policy advocacy to better equip communities as they recover from natural disasters.  For Chrishelle Palay, the last year has been monumental.  As a recent graduate of the Executive Master of Urban Planning (EMUP) online program, the degree has already propelled her career path ‚Äî even if urban planning was a slight departure from her previous positions.  Palay‚Äôs educational journey began when she attended Prairie View A&M University, an HBCU in Texas, where she pursued her bachelor‚Äôs degree in architecture. She spent the next two decades in the field, working as a designer for high-rise residential projects throughout the U.S. before she decided to pursue a different, related passion: housing policy advocacy.  ‚ÄúI transitioned from architecture because I realized it wasn‚Äôt something I wanted to do anymore. Actually, Hurricane Ike kind of led to that realization, as I saw that there are so many communities that didn‚Äôt have the skill sets to understand and navigate how to recover from disaster,‚Äù Palay explained.  Palay began working with members from low-income communities to advocate on their behalf for better housing and living conditions, and she is now the director for Houston Organizing Movement for Equity (HOME), a Texan coalition of community-based organizations focused on repairing the state in the aftermath of Hurricane Harvey.  While Palay was passionate about her new career focus and its emphasis on creating a more equitable, resilient city ‚Äî and felt her background in architecture helped her successfully navigate the systems involved ‚Äî she wanted to deepen her knowledge in urban planning.  ‚ÄúI was always touching the periphery of urban planning, but I never had a chance to really dive into it. The thought of pursuing a master‚Äôs in urban planning was on my mind because I thought if I was even better equipped, I could do deeper work that really helps my community members,‚Äù she explained.  Then, Palay met a Trojan graduate who had just completed the EMUP online program at USC Price School of Policy. After they raved to Palay about the executive master‚Äôs program, she realized it was time to pursue urban planning ‚Äî specifically at USC.  ‚ÄúEveryone knows that USC has a very prestigious reputation, so I was a bit intimidated initially. I thought that because I‚Äôm in community work and not at this high-profile architecture firm, I don‚Äôt know if I‚Äôll really cut the mustard,‚Äù Palay mused. ‚ÄúAnd so, I was pleasantly surprised when I actually was accepted. Just to be part of the USC family is something that I never thought was within reach.‚Äù  As Palay navigated her way through the program, she realized how well the curriculum melded not only with her future career goals, but also with her current position at the HOME Coalition ‚Äî especially involving her work with local policymakers and community leaders.  ‚ÄúMany of the courses that I took and the conversations I had with professors and the assignments I did definitely [blended] with my lived experience,‚Äù she explained. ‚ÄúI gained so much value from the coursework and being in the program.‚Äù  Tailored to working professionals who want to make their cities more equitable, sustainable and just, the EMUP online trains graduates to become leaders in the public, nonprofit or private sectors. It also emphasizes collaboration and community, immersing students in projects with their peers and professors to address real-world issues.  Palay was particularly fond of her diverse cohort members. Although her colleagues came from different backgrounds and held varying perspectives on the field, each of their professional work ‚Äúhad a link to urban planning in some way, shape or form.‚Äù  ‚ÄúMy background is architecture and housing policy advocacy, but now I got to understand through the perspective of someone who‚Äôs been working in development, from the perspective of someone that works within finance, someone else who works through the lens of leading homelessness issues or efforts within their community,‚Äù she said.  The faculty and staff were also immensely supportive, fostering a virtual classroom environment in which all students felt compelled to share their points of view and ‚Äúshow up‚Äù for one another.  ‚ÄúRegardless of our personal or professional responsibilities, everyone in the cohort always showed up in class. It was almost like a responsibility that we had for each other, even though it was unspoken,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúOf course, the program was online, so it made it even more special to form that connection. It had that feel of family despite being behind screens.‚Äù  Following her graduation this year, Palay feels even more invigorated by her career, and she is currently looking to deepen her experience in the advocacy sector and broaden her scope to focus on connecting local-based issues with federal policy changes.  ‚Äú[I want] to use the skill sets that I‚Äôve learned and also utilize the connections I‚Äôve made,‚Äù she said.  When asked where she visualizes her career in the future, Palay described working on a global level to enact more serious change when it comes to disaster relief and recovery, boosting her impact to an international scale.  ‚ÄúI want to be doing all I can to be a policy advocate and a bridge builder for equitable disaster recovery so that low-income communities ‚Äî the most vulnerable communities that are impacted by disaster ‚Äî are able to have the tools to recover. [I want to ensure] we also have equitable policy that allows folks to really recover and not be set back,‚Äù she said.  It‚Äôs a noble goal, and one Palay seems well-suited to accomplish, especially with her master‚Äôs degree from USC Price in hand. After taking a moment to look forward, she also reflected on what she would tell other people considering the EMUP program. She was unwavering in her enthusiasm: If you‚Äôre passionate about urban planning, go for it.  ‚ÄúLay aside any reservations that you may have. It will be a rigorous program, but a transformative experience ‚Ä¶ You will have a community of support both from the faculty and the students,‚Äù she said.  Learn more about the Executive Master of Urban Planning online program at USC Price today.

SITTWE, Myanmar ‚Äì Satellite images released by Maxar are providing a new look at the scope of catastrophic damage left in the wake of Cyclone Mocha, which slammed into Myanmar on Sunday as one of the most powerful cyclones to ever hit the country.  The striking photos were taken on Monday above Sittwe, the area where Cyclone Mocha made landfall, and were compared to those that were taken on Feb. 17. Monday's images show significant damage to buildings and infrastructure caused by the powerful storm.  5 DIFFERENT NAMES FOR HURRICANES AROUND THE WORLD  Cyclone Mocha was packing winds of 175 mph as it spun toward the coast of Myanmar on Sunday. Those wind speeds are the equivalent of a Category 5 hurricane on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale.  More than 100,000 people in Myanmar‚Äôs Rakhine state were told to flee ahead of the monster storm, with many seeking shelter in monasteries, schools and religious sites, as others were told to get to higher ground to escape the onslaught of water rushing inland in addition to the torrential rainfall, according to an update from the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA).  Those who didn't leave were forced to the higher floors of buildings and onto roofs to escape the water rushing inland due to the storm surge.  The image above shows the scope of devastation from Cyclone Mocha's winds and flooding.  The before image shows buildings and religious sites surrounded by blue water and white beaches. After Cyclone Mocha, the buildings appeared to be destroyed. The white sand is littered with debris, and the water is no longer clear.  Another set of before and after satellite images shows the bright blue roofs of buildings and trees lining streets in the surrounding community. Most of the roofs were blown away, and only the foundations of many buildings remained after the storm.  The cataclysmic winds from Cyclone Mocha also crumpled cell phone towers and destroyed electrical transformers, effectively cutting off communications to a large swath of the country.  At least six deaths have been reported, but fears are growing that the death toll could rise significantly as communication is slowly restored and more information is received.

RALEIGH ‚Äî Teuvo Teravainen‚Äôs roughly monthlong injury absence appears to be near an end.  The Carolina Hurricanes forward has shed his no-contact jersey and participated in a full practice Monday ahead of the Eastern Conference Final against Florida. Teravainen hasn‚Äôt played since he suffered a hand injury in Game 2 of the first-round series against the New York Islanders.  It‚Äôs unclear exactly when he might be ready to play, though his return would be a lift for a team that has kept advancing despite injuries to top-line forwards.  ‚ÄúI think I‚Äôm pretty much ready to go,‚Äù Teravainen said after Monday‚Äôs practice. ‚ÄúSo whenever coach puts me out there, I‚Äôll be good.‚Äù  Rod Brind‚ÄôAmour wouldn‚Äôt say definitively when that would be, though he noted the extra rest from the series schedule ‚Äî still unset as of Monday‚Äôs practice ‚Äî could help.  ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs healthy enough,‚Äù Brind‚ÄôAmour said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just whether or not he can play. ... I‚Äôm not going to throw him in if he can‚Äôt shoot.‚Äù  Teravainen was hurt when New York‚Äôs Jean-Gabriel Pageau struck the forward‚Äôs hands in an uncalled slashing penalty, with an angry Brind‚ÄôAmour saying afterward that Pageau ‚Äúabsolutely tomahawk chops him, absolutely.‚Äù  At the time, Brind‚ÄôAmour had said Teravainen had a broken hand that would require surgery. More specifically, the injury turned out to be Teravainen‚Äôs left thumb, evidenced by the thick pinkish-brown scar running through the center and along the length of his thumb that was visible as he spoke to reporters in the locker room.  He had recently returned to skating with a few teammates and had been building up his on-ice work. On Monday, that meant rotating in on the penalty kill and other stretches of practice.  Wednesday marks four weeks since the April 19 injury, with surgery following the next day.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs kind of crazy, I thought for sure I was done (for the playoffs),‚Äù Teravainen said. ‚ÄúBut the doctors made a really good job and it looks like I‚Äôm getting back pretty soon. ... The boys have done a really good job playing really good hockey. It‚Äôs tough to watch games from the outside. You always want to be helping, but they‚Äôve done a really good job.‚Äù  The Hurricanes entered the playoffs with concerns about the offense after losing forwards Max Pacioretty and Andrei Svechnikov to season-ending injuries. Carolina had acquired Pacioretty in an offseason trade from Vegas to improve its scoring depth among the top six forwards, while Svechnikov is a physical presence who has been a core piece in the team‚Äôs current five-year run of playoff appearances.  Teravainen‚Äôs injury only compounded those worries as a top-line forward and strong passer who is also valuable on the penalty kill. But the Hurricanes have rolled along regardless in returning to the semifinals of the Stanley Cup Playoffs for the first time since 2019.  Carolina‚Äôs penalty kill is ranked No. 1 among all playoff teams (90%), with the Hurricanes tallying more shorthanded goals (four) than power-play goals allowed (three).  As for the offense, Carolina has seen an uptick in its offensive production for the playoffs (3.64) from the regular season (3.20) behind a collective approach. That produced a dozen different goal scorers, including four players with three each, in the five-game series against the New Jersey Devils in Round 2.  Teravainen can only help both areas once Brind‚ÄôAmour and team medical staff are certain he‚Äôs ready.  ‚ÄúI saw he switched jerseys today so obviously a good sign,‚Äù Carolina captain Jordan Staal said. ‚ÄúAnd just in general, him skating around, he looks great. I‚Äôm sure he‚Äôs feeling good and starting to move towards getting in the lineup. ... He‚Äôs been a big part of our group for a long time and he‚Äôs a heck of a player, so we‚Äôll take him when we can.‚Äù

The Florida Panthers will face the Carolina Hurricanes in the Eastern Conference Finals of the 2023 Stanley Cup Finals starting on Thursday, May 18.  The Panthers advanced to the finals after defeating the Boston Bruins in seven games in the first round and the Toronto Maple Leafs in five games in the second round. The Hurricanes knocked off the New York Islanders in the first round in six games and then the New Jersey Devils in five games.  Game one of the Eastern Conference Finals will be on Thursday, May 18 at 8 p.m. EST on TNT. Fans looking to catch the action live can shop for tickets online using VividSeats, StubHub and SeatGeek. As of Tuesday, May 16, the cheapest tickets to game one are $89 on VividSeats, $99 on StubHub and $88 on SeatGeek. SUNRISE ‚Äî For Florida Panthers fans of a certain age, it had to be strange when former Carolina Hurricanes captain Eric Staal signed with the team as he had some real battles with the likes of Olli Jokinen, Stephen Weiss and Nathan Horton back in the day.  Nothing as strange as what some Carolina fans have to be feeling right now.  The former Carolina captain will be back in Raleigh this week trying to get his team to the Stanley Cup Final ‚Äî only he will not be leading the Hurricanes but battling them.  ‚ÄúThis is huge, a great opportunity for us and we‚Äôre not satisfied with where we are at,‚Äù Staal told FHN on Monday afternoon.  ‚ÄúWe feel really good about our game and are confident in our ability but we know this is going to be a huge challenge. They are a great team, they have had a great season thus far. They play a committed game and we feel we do as well. It‚Äôs going to be tight, fighting for every inch.‚Äù  Jump on the Bandwagon!  Everything You Need to Impress Your Friends Is Here  Get a Subscription to Florida Hockey Now, Today!  Staal, 38, spent his first 12 seasons with the Hurricanes and remains the franchise‚Äôs post-Hartford leader in games played, goals, assists and points.  Ron Francis remains the combined franchise leader with 1,175 points ‚Äî 821 of them coming with the Whalers.  Although Staal has been away from the Hurricanes for a while, it is still a place near and dear to his heart.  It is where he got his start, it is where he enjoyed his greatest moment as an NHL player and it is where he helped grow the game into a truly Carolina thing these days.  When he first started in Raleigh, games were sparsely attended but today the Hurricanes play in a madhouse on Edwards Mill Road.  Staal says he is looking forward to returning to Raleigh with the Panthers on Wednesday ‚Äî but it will not be for a reunion.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs over already,‚Äô‚Äô Staal said. ‚ÄúAt this point, I am here with all my brothers right here in this room, in this group and we are committed to winning a series and moving on to the next round and a chance for something else.  ‚ÄúI obviously have a lot of respect for them, a lot of friendships over there. But they‚Äôre probably saying the same thing: Put it all aside for the time being. I am one of the pieces here in trying to make this team successful. We just want to get the job done.‚Äù  Staal won the Stanley Cup with the Hurricanes in 2006 after being the second-overall pick of Carolina in 2003. Florida had the first overall pick in that draft but traded it to Pittsburgh and dropped to third.  The Penguins took goalie Marc-Andre Fleury and Carolina jumped at the chance to take Staal. Florida was set on taking Horton, hence the trade with the Penguins.  He stayed there until 2016 when Carolina traded him at the deadline to the Rangers so he could chase the Cup with New York ‚Äî and younger brother Marc.  Now both are with the Panthers and will be squaring off on the second Staal to wear the ‚ÄòC‚Äô in Raleigh as Jordan Staal is the current captain of the Hurricanes.  This will be a reunion ‚Äî or revenge ‚Äî series on many fronts as Florida coach Paul Maurice was the last coach of the Whalers and the first coach of the Hurricanes.  He spent parts of 11 seasons with the franchise in two different stints and not only coached current Carolina bench boss Rod Brind‚ÄôAmour but all of his assistants as well.  Florida also has former Carolina players Eetu Luostarinen and Gus Forsling as well as assistant coach Tuomo Ruutu (2008-14).  ‚ÄúWe have a few connections, right? But I am quite removed. It has been a decade for me,‚Äù Maurice said Monday afternoon. ‚ÄúEric has played for a bunch of other teams since then, went to the Finals with Montreal. ‚Ä¶ There are probably five or six important people in my life who still live there and I will get to see them.  ‚ÄúThe thing that always gets me when we go back is the height of the trees (around the arena). They were just planting them when we got there and now you can‚Äôt see the building for the trees. That‚Äôs what I notice, how much has changed. ‚Ä¶ But it‚Äôs not nearly as nostalgic as you might think. I‚Äôm not driving by the old house.‚Äù  While Maurice will not be cruising around his old neighborhood when he gets back into town, Staal figures he will check out some former haunts.  While the Panthers plan to have a team dinner upon arrival Wednesday, there will be down time during the series and players will be free to check things out as they are wont to do.  If anyone needs a suggestion on where to go, well, they know exactly who to ask.  ‚ÄúI will probably find a dinner spot for the guys when we are there,‚Äù Staal said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll enjoy our time together as teammates. We‚Äôll find something. There are a lot of great places in Raleigh. I know a few of them. Hopefully it is with the wins in the column.‚Äù  FLORIDA PANTHERS ON DECK  STANLEY CUP PLAYOFFS  EASTERN CONFERENCE FINALS  PANTHERS (WC2) AT CAROLINA HURRICANES (MET1)  GAME 1

AMELIA ISLAND, Florida ‚Äî For now, the ACC is sticking together, even as some members admit they will keep their ears to the ground as conference realignment widens the revenue gap among the Power Five conferences in college athletics.  Questions concerning the health of the ACC dominated three days of meetings at the conference's annual spring summit at the Ritz-Carlton tucked in the northeast corner of Florida. The worst-kept secret among members finally went public as athletic directors entered their first meeting Monday afternoon: seven of the 14 full-time members had partnered together to examine the conference's grant of rights and whether it was possible to form their own union or seek membership in the expanding SEC and Big Ten.  In public, it appeared a battle line was drawn between the 14 schools, but when the smoke settled following a four-hour meeting behind closed doors Monday among athletic directors, commissioner Jim Phillips exited confident, if not exactly assured, his conference's membership would remain unchanged in the coming years.  "What I what I've been told is, we're all in this together ‚Äî emphatically," Phillips said. "We believe in the ACC, we believe in where we're going and we want to continue to work together."  Still, there was nowhere to hide from reality Wednesday. This was no place to hide behind anonymously-sourced reports or discount whispers of discontent as nothing more than conjecture on social media. Seven schools ‚Äî Clemson, Florida State, Miami, North Carolina, North Carolina State, Virginia and Virginia Tech ‚Äî had, in fact, partnered together to explore the possibility of leaving the ACC.  "That's not a warning sign to me that something bad may happen," Phillips said. "These are schools that are under a lot of stress and a lot of pressures, and I understand that, I really do. The reality is our conference is third in the country in (revenue) distribution. As we look at the projections, at least in this decade, we're going to continue to be there. We want to close the gap ‚Äî we need to close the gap ‚Äî between the top two conferences that have started to run away from us."  Several schools among the seven will keep their eyes on other possibilities, even as they work within the ACC to improve the health of the conference.  "The landscape is changing significantly," Clemson athletics director Graham Neff told 247Sports. "My role is to be connected and well-read in the industry and with all of our universities, and that starts in the ACC."  Clemson and Florida State led those seven schools as they embarked on exploratory trips to the ACC's headquarters to study the league's grant of rights and the voluminous language in a separate document authored by ESPN. What they discovered was the contract through 2036 is difficult to break without facing significant financial penalties estimated to carry a price tag between $120 million and $500 million, industry sources tell 247Sports.  ‚ÄúI absolutely feel for my colleagues (Monday) that were blindsided, and if the commissioner was, him as well," Virginia Tech athletics director Whit Babcock told The Richmond Times-Dispatch. "These jobs are hard enough without something knocking you upside the head. ... There was probably a number of things said [Monday] that needed to be said. I think the commissioner did a great job with it. You‚Äôve got 15 schools and 15 different approaches. After the initial shock of some of the news reported, I think it was productive after that. I think it was less than ideal that it came out, but it‚Äôs been a catalyst for some real conversation and maybe getting to things a little faster that we‚Äôve been working on as the ACC.‚Äù  Florida State athletics director Michael Alford has been the most vocal opponent of the current revenue distribution within the conference. He entertained questions about leaving the ACC during a board of trustees meeting at FSU in February and also issued a warning to conference leadership demanding more money from the ACC's coffers.  In the wake of progress on an unequal revenue distribution system he supported, Alford said Tuesday FSU is "very thrilled to be in this league and we want to stay." He termed exploration as "due diligence" in the wake of the massive realignment waves in the Pac-12, Big Ten, SEC and Big 12, adding that reports of the ACC's potential demise were "overblown." Nearly every program in the ACC has studied the league's grant of rights at the ACC's headquarters over the last two years, sources tell 247Sports.  "We're going to continue to do what's best for Clemson," Neff said. "That means strengthening and supporting the ACC and being a proud member, but also just making sure that we're very connected (in the industry) in doing what's best for Clemson."  The ACC paid an average of $36.1 million to each team in the 2021 fiscal year. The baseline share for programs would not drop year to year in a new model, which will reward programs for their success with bonus payouts for their success in the postseason, most notably in the College Football Playoff and men's and women's basketball tournaments. Ambitious estimates project bonuses could range from $10 million to $20 million for the top-earning university. The ACC's board of directors is "excited" about the model, Phillips said, but more details need to be finalized before a vote is conducted. The new revenue-sharing model should be adopted later this summer, a source told 247Sports.  Florida State pushed for television revenue to also be included in the merit-based system but it did not gain traction. "One bridge at a time," Alford said.  Conference realignment has often coincided with the expiration of media rights contracts. That could mean trouble, again, for the ACC when the Big Ten's massive $7 billion deal announced in 2022 expires in 2030, and the SEC's exclusive deal with ESPN expires in 2034. The ACC's deal spans through 2036.  "At the end of the day, we are better off together than a smaller subset," Phillips said. "It's been proven that national championships are great when you have multiple leagues competing for it, not just a couple," Phillips said. "I feel really good about the future of the ACC. I do. And I'm not just saying that."

#TurksandCaicos, May 15, 2023 ‚Äì The out-of-control population, especially for the growth of stray dogs alongside what appears to be quasi ownership and neglect, is overwhelming for some communities in Grand Turk.  Packs of dogs chasing cars, bicycles and golf carts are no longer a laughing matter. This coupled with constant howling at wee hours of the night is often times unbearable.  Most would agree stray dogs and wild donkeys are an issue, but there will always be a fierce debate over how best to respond.  It places focus on an issue that long divided opinions. The question that remains is, what to do with TCI‚Äôs vast number of stray animals?  Like many others, I‚Äôm a dog owner and some years ago, adopted two of my own. Quite frankly, I do have a sensitive side to animals. The donkeys are unique in a sense, charming, and because of their friendly nature, most tourists treat them as an open petting zoo.  Nevertheless, as pet owners we should have some kind of responsibility when it comes to properly caring for and the protection of these beautiful animals.  I realize like many Caribbean countries, it‚Äôs an island culture to allow your animals to roam freely. Nevertheless, the mere exponential growth of these two animals, particularly on the island of Grand Turk, is out of control.  We must come to the realization that we are no longer living in the 70s and 80‚Äôs with a limited number of vehicles on the streets.  Over the years, there have been reports of serious vehicle accidents as a result of these loose animals roaming the streets. In addition, these out of control animals are rummaging through residential garbage bins and contributing to issue the island is having with littering.  With the increasing number of stray dogs that are traveling in packs, it could also present a danger to citizens and tourists alike. Prior to the pandemic, an island-wide charitable spay and neuter program which was spearheaded by the TCSPCA, was underway. Despite the great success, it appears the program is not garnering the support it deserves.  A lack of continued neutering and spaying, will lead to the uncontrolled breeding of pets and wild animals. Unfortunately, with the high cost of animal care, many residents cannot afford the vet‚Äôs bills for injured or malnourished animals.  A few years ago, there was a new approach by the government with proposed laws that would have helped to deal with the situation, to include possible quarantine of the donkeys. I‚Äôm not a veterinarian, therefore, I cannot speak to what impact this would have on donkeys who have been introduced to the wild for such a long period of time.  Nonetheless, let‚Äôs consider the alternative, the laws still need to be tightened up and enforced, this will prevent accidental harm to humans and to the animals themselves.  Many citizens have raised concerns that cruelty and animal neglect complaints are not being treated as seriously or investigated as robustly as they should be. With the growth in human population over the years and changes in society, it should no longer be acceptable to own pets without having a properly fenced yard, and or a requirement to have them on a leash.  This long-standing issue is a very sensitive one, especially in Grand Turk, where the donkeys have become a part of the character of this beautiful by nature island.  I believe the solution lies in educating the public and possibly the need for a slight shift in cultural norms. Better yet, maybe it‚Äôs time for the government to incentivize owners to get their dogs spayed and neutered and fund direct investment in such clinics.  The recent announcement of a prison initiative to assist with caring for injured donkeys is an exceptionally good idea. Hopefully the department of agriculture can capitalize on this project.  According to Dr Brent, the local quarantine officer, his department has been tasked with developing a strategy to present to cabinet for consideration and approval. One of the immediate needs is a proper animal transport vehicle.  Here are a few other ideas to ponder.  -Can some of the donkeys be relocated to one of our deserted cays where they can roam freely?  -Can we export some of the animals to our neighboring country like Haiti, where they can be put to good use?  -Can we set up a sanctuary for these donkeys at north wells and create a real petting zoo, with an entry fee and all funds are reinvested for their care?  -Can the government commit to working in concert with TCSPCA to increase the number of spayed and neutered clinics across these islands?  At the end of the day, we can still live in harmony with these beautiful animals. Henceforth, the issue must be addressed and given more attention. If we fail to do so, it will only continue to create an endless cycle of need, animal abuse and neglect.  Ed Forbes  Concerned citizen of Grand Turk

The three men behind the Carolina Hurricanes‚Äô bench, Rod Brind‚ÄôAmour, Jeff Daniels and Tim Gleason, all played in different, overlapping eras for the Hurricanes.  They all had one coach in common.  Paul Maurice coached Brind‚ÄôAmour and Daniels in his first stint here, and Gleason in his second, and it‚Äôs hard to imagine many coaches can say the same of their playoff opponents.  Twelve years have passed since Maurice was fired here, not for the first time, and so much has changed. The owner. The longtime general manager. A decade-long playoff drought came and went. Eric Staal left, and Sebastian Aho arrived, and Brind‚ÄôAmour went from assistant coach to head coach.  Maurice, meanwhile, coached the Toronto Maple Leafs between his two tenures and 381 wins with the Hurricanes, went to Russia after his second and spent nine seasons with the Winnipeg Jets before walking away last winter, only to resurface this season with the Florida Panthers ‚Äî a team of which big things was expected in the regular season that has finally delivered in the playoffs.  Just about everything comes full circle if you wait long enough, and now the coach who brought Brind‚ÄôAmour into coaching has taken a fourth team to the conference finals, and for the first time the Hurricanes stand in his way.  ‚ÄúI just remember watching him do it, saying I‚Äôll never be a coach,‚Äù Brind‚ÄôAmour said this week. ‚ÄùHe‚Äôs up here, the way he thinks. I was like, oh man, if it has to be like that, I‚Äôm probably not going to be able to do it. Obviously, I found a different way to kind of do it.‚Äù  That cerebral side of Maurice often goes overlooked, his deep understanding of the game buried under the quips for the media, the f-bombs for officials. But even without having ever played in the league, he always found a way to get the most out his players, whether they were grizzled veterans (in 2002, when the Hurricanes could afford character but not talent) or the last proud remnants of a championship team (in 2009).  Story continues  It‚Äôs almost impossible now to fathom the difficulty of the task Maurice faced when the Hartford Whalers moved to Raleigh in 1997, their 30-year-old head coach being asked to shepherd the team through two interim years in Greensboro with a minuscule payroll before trying to put down hockey roots in a basketball market.  Somehow, he and the Hurricanes both made it to the other side.  ‚ÄúIt also seems quite removed to me,‚Äù Maurice told reporters in Florida on Monday. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been a decade.‚Äù  Deep ties to Carolina  There are so many familiar ex-Hurricanes playing key roles for the Panthers in this playoff series: Eric Staal, Zac Dalpe, Gustav Forsling, Tuomo Ruutu, Eetu Luostarinen ‚Äî and, in the front office, Paul Krepelka, the assistant general manager who helped build the Hurricanes into a playoff team before moving to Florida and doing the same for the Panthers, and whose fingerprints are on the roster in a way Ron Francis‚Äô are not, no matter what you might hear on national TV.  But even Staal‚Äôs ties to the Hurricanes don‚Äôt run as deep as Maurice‚Äôs, even if both will inevitably someday join Brind‚ÄôAmour, Francis, Glen Wesley and Cam Ward in the Hurricanes Hall of Fame.  From the moment Maurice sat in the back of a press conference discussing the possibility of the team moving to Raleigh paging through a Triangle real-estate guide, the 30-year-old head coach of the soon-to-be-no-longer Hartford Whalers, his existence, his future, was inseparable from the Hurricanes‚Äô early days here.  ‚ÄúThe franchise in Hartford-slash-Carolina was in, I would say, disarray,‚Äù Maurice said earlier this postseason, and it‚Äôs hard to argue the point.  He was the one told by a linesman to quit swearing in the Greensboro Coliseum, because kids could hear him in the empty arena. He was the one who maneuvered a moderately talented but extremely disciplined team to within three wins of the Stanley Cup, losing only to a roster overflowing with Hall of Famers. He was the target of a banner reading ‚ÄúMo Must Go‚Äù that PNC Arena security removed from the 300 level in November 2003, putting in print a popular chant among the disgruntled.  He was finally fired many years after he was supposed to be ‚Äî perennially in those early years, he was the top name on every pundit‚Äôs ‚Äúfirst coach to be fired‚Äù lists, and never was ‚Äî then made a triumphant return by guiding the Hurricanes back to the playoffs and to a long postseason run in 2009, before getting fired again.  Still, Maurice was around for all of the franchise‚Äôs early moments in North Carolina and some of its more important later ones, if not the most important of all. His first departure opened the door for Peter Laviolette, who in his first full season guided the Hurricanes to the Stanley Cup in 2006. When Laviolette faltered in the fall of 2008, Maurice stepped back in.  ‚ÄúI helped get him fired, because I was part of the team that got him fired, and part of getting him hired, the second time around,‚Äù Brind‚ÄôAmour said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs got a long history here, but he doesn‚Äôt care about that, and I don‚Äôt either.‚Äù  ‚ÄòAlways willing‚Äô  Maurice was a polarizing figure at times, a lightning rod for frustration with a franchise that couldn‚Äôt spend like other teams in the pre-cap era, but he also deserves tremendous credit for getting the most out of the roster in 2002, switching goalies on the fly and taking on Scotty Bowman head-to-head. That improbable run cemented the franchise‚Äôs future here, removing doubt from what had been a tenuous existence to that point.  Someone had to get the Hurricanes through the two years in Greensboro, to build some kind of momentum on the ice, to find some kind of postseason success. It just happened to be a coach who was, at the time, younger than a number of his players.  ‚ÄúThe thing about Paul, with the maturity he had, he accepted whatever the situation was,‚Äù former Hurricanes general manager Jim Rutherford said. ‚ÄúWe had very challenging situations in the early years in Raleigh and Paul never complained about it. He was always willing to take on the challenge.‚Äù  Maurice was also more closely linked to his general manager (Rutherford) and owner (Peter Karmanos) than most coaches ever are. His playing career ended with an eye injury in junior hockey, playing for Karmanos‚Äô team. Karmanos and Rutherford brought him along, from junior coach to NHL assistant to precocious head coach, all of which made Maurice an easy target for fans dissatisfied with the team‚Äôs overall direction.  When you start that young, it leaves a lot of runway. He won his 1,000th game when he was 43, before many coaches blow their first whistle. Only Bowman, Barry Trotz and Joel Quenneville have coached more games in the NHL; Maurice has won more games than peers like Peter Laviolette, Mike Babcock and the late Pat Quinn. His spotless Game 7 record includes two wins with the Hurricanes.  The first time he came back to Raleigh as an opposing coach, in December 2006 with the Leafs, he noticed something few others would: The trees around PNC Arena had grown up and filled in, blocking the view from the team bus. He mentioned the trees again this week, now an additional 16 years older and bigger, as he comes back for the first time as a playoff opponent, this fragile sapling of a franchise he once nurtured having become a mighty oak in these many years without him.  ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not nearly as nostalgic as you might think,‚Äù Maurice said. ‚ÄúAll three of my kids were born there. But I‚Äôm not driving past the house.‚Äù  Never miss a Luke DeCock column. Sign up at tinyurl.com/lukeslatest to have them delivered directly to your email inbox as soon as they post. Many of the players on the Carolina Hurricanes‚Äô current roster have been around long enough to say they‚Äôve been to a conference final series ‚Äî many of them with the Canes in 2019.  Nine players on the Canes‚Äô current roster skated with the team that year in the Eastern Conference final, falling to the Boston Bruins in a clinical 4-0 sweep. At last a half-dozen others skated for teams who made it to a conference final before joining this year‚Äôs group, which will skate in the Eastern Conference final against the Florida Panthers beginning Thursday.  So, ho hum, another conference final, right?  Not so much.  ‚ÄúI remember some of the veteran guys on the 2019 team, and (coach) Rod (Brind‚ÄôAmour) saying you don‚Äôt know when or even if you‚Äôll get back to the conference finals,‚Äù Canes defenseman Brett Pesce said Tuesday. ‚ÄúWe kind of learned that the hard way, so I think just appreciating where you are not taking a day for granted will be the key. We owe this to Raleigh and North Carolina.‚Äù  They ‚Äúowe it to Raleigh‚Äù? It‚Äôs no shock that Pesce feels that way. He‚Äôs a New York native and played college hockey in New Hampshire, but all of Pesce‚Äôs professional hockey has been played in North Carolina. He had a brief stay in Charlotte with the Checkers in the AHL before a quick promotion to the Hurricanes, for whom he‚Äôs been a mainstay since 2015.  ‚ÄúIt makes me just appreciate just everything this team has been through,‚Äù Pesce said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve kind of started from the bottom and here we are now. It‚Äôs cool. Raleigh has a special place in my heart and to be here (in the conference final) again is super cool.‚Äù  Another of the Canes‚Äô American-born defenders, Jaccob Slavin has followed a nearly identical path to Pesce, playing first at the NCAA Division I level before a brief stint in Charlotte and then a quick promotion to the Hurricanes, in the same season as Pesce.  ‚ÄúAnything to help continue to build that momentum is good,‚Äù Slavin said. ‚ÄúAnd then you get to something like the Eastern Conference final, (the fans) are going nuts already, everyone‚Äôs excited about it. People I talk to outside the rink are excited about it ‚Ä¶ continuing to build the community we have here in Raleigh. Hopefully we have a better showing than the last time we were in the Eastern Conference final.‚Äù  Story continues  As Slavin was also quick to point out, reaching a conference final is great, but it‚Äôs also not the ultimate goal.  ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre close, but we‚Äôre also only halfway,‚Äù Slavin said. ‚ÄúWe have eight wins, but we still have eight more to go, so it‚Äôs a long path and it‚Äôs definitely not going to get any easier. It‚Äôs exciting to be where we‚Äôre at, but there‚Äôs a lot of work to do still.‚Äù  A new tradition?  There‚Äôs something unique about this year‚Äôs collection of NHL final four teams: None of them has an average daily high temperature below 70 degrees. Indeed, Raleigh is the coldest of the bunch, at about 71 degrees. Dallas follows at 78, Las Vegas at 80 and Miami/Sunrise at a balmy 84.  Some observers in ‚Äútraditional‚Äù hockey markets have found that quirk a bit unsettling.  Not the Canes.  The Carolina Hurricanes Jaccob Slavin (74) and Jordan Staal (11) take turns shooting from the kneeling position during practice on Monday, May 15, 2023 at PNC Arena in Raleigh, N.C. Robert Willett/rwillett@newsobserver.com  ‚ÄúIt speaks a lot to what those markets have done,‚Äù Slavin said. ‚ÄúLook at Tampa, the last three years going to the Stanley Cup (final) every year and building their market down there. All the teams that are the last ones standing right now, speaks to what they‚Äôre trying to do, and how they‚Äôre engaged with the game. It‚Äôs cool to see, it‚Äôs great for the game, building the game across all different demographics.‚Äù  Brind‚ÄôAmour agreed, tracing the national growth to a specific event in 1988.  ‚ÄúIt says a lot about how the game has grown, number one, that we brought it to places and fans that never would have thought 20 or 30 years ago, you wouldn‚Äôt have envisioned this,‚Äù Brind‚ÄôAmour said. ‚ÄúYou can trace it back to, in my opinion, in the late ‚Äô80s when (Wayne) Gretzky got traded to L.A. I think it spawned a whole new awareness for people in the States and hockey, and now here we are. It‚Äôs not surprising these teams are good, the whole league is good. It‚Äôs just where they‚Äôve put these teams. Hockey‚Äôs a great game, people love it, as we know.‚Äù  While a veteran hockey market compared with Las Vegas, Raleigh is still the second-newest of the bunch at 25 years. The Minnesota North Stars relocated to Dallas in 1993, while Florida was awarded an expansion franchise to start playing that same season. Vegas‚Äô first season in the NHL was in 2017.  ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no doubt things have changed for the better,‚Äù Brind‚ÄôAmour said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve grown as a team, a community, as everything. I think it‚Äôs been a real positive growth.‚Äù  The Carolina Hurricanes Brett Pesce (22) works on his shooting form during their practice on Monday, May 15, 2023 at PNC Arena in Raleigh, N.C. Robert Willett/rwillett@newsobserver.com  Staying cool  While staying cool in any of the remaining cities among the NHL‚Äôs final four may be a challenge in the physical, sun-on-their-neck sense, the ability to remain cool and calm under pressure ‚Äî and while being agitated ‚Äî on the ice will be paramount for any team‚Äôs success.  With Florida Panthers players like Matthew Tkachuk and Radko Gudas ‚Äî whose considerable talents include among them ‚ÄúGrade-A pest‚Äù ‚Äî coming to town for the Eastern Conference final, it will be important for the Hurricanes to follow the lead of a player like Slavin, whose ability to remain calm and play tough without retaliation rubs off on the rest of the team.  ‚ÄúIt helps, I mean, Slavin against anybody is going to help,‚Äù Brind‚ÄôAmour said.  Asked specifically about Tkachuk, Brind‚ÄôAmour added: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure he gets under your skin a little, but if there‚Äôs a guy that‚Äôs pretty calm and cool about that, I mean, Jaccob doesn‚Äôt get rattled. We‚Äôre going to have to be dialed in on that and play the game the way we need to play, whistle to whistle and not get caught up in that stuff, because that‚Äôs obviously not to our advantage.‚Äù  Slavin wasn‚Äôt worried about the potential for post-whistle activity, either, with Tkachuk or anyone else.  At least, not for himself.  ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs going to be the type of player he is,‚Äù Slavin said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a really good player, you just try not to get dragged into any of it. I know for myself, that‚Äôs fairly easy, but yeah, it‚Äôs going to be fun. He‚Äôs a fun player to play against and he‚Äôs effective at what he does. We have to make sure we stay disciplined against it.‚Äù  As for the rest of the group?  ‚ÄúThis whole group, we‚Äôve seen it in other series, it didn‚Äôt, that stuff doesn‚Äôt rattle us,‚Äù Brind‚ÄôAmour said, ‚Äúand I think because of the people we have in there ‚Äî Jaccob‚Äôs one of them, Skjei‚Äôs one of them, Pesce ‚Äî none of these guys, they have a job to do and you know they‚Äôre going to try and do it.‚Äù

BUTTERFLY HURRICANE have released a new music video!  The new music video, for the track Barricade, is the debut single from the alternative rock artist. His music intends to be deeply personal and emotive, exploring the impact of Crohn‚Äôs disease on his life and mental health.  Speaking about the debut single, the artist says, ‚Äúa lot of my lyrics come from my battles with Crohn‚Äôs disease and how it has affected my personal life and the lives of others. This song in is essentially me venting my frustrations on how I wish I could be someone else and just have a day not having to plan my life around this disease. It‚Äôs not all doom and gloom though, the struggle is part of the beauty. It‚Äôs helped me grow and realise what‚Äôs important in life.‚Äù  Watch the official music video for Barricade here:  For more information on BUTTERFLY HURRICANE like their official page on Facebook.

C√©line Paquette and Joey Kirchner on Bachelor in Paradise Canada Season 2, hosted by Sharleen Joynt. Full episodes at Citytv.com and on Citytv+.  It didn't take long for things to get messy on Bachelor in Paradise Canada, hosted by Sharleen Joynt (Mondays 8 p.m. ET/PT on Citytv, catch up on Citytv.com and on Citytv+).  The latest episodes started off with the return of "Hurricane Demi," Bachelor alumni Demi Burnett, who made the singles "get real" with a series of questions to reveal their true feelings about each other.  Samantha "Sam" Picco from St. John's took the first shot, saying that The Bachelor Canada Season 3 star, Lisa Mancini from St. Catharines, Ont., is the person in paradise putting out "toxic vibes." This came after Lisa kissed Quartney Mixon and Connor Brennan, both from The Bachelorette Season 17.  C√©line Paquette from Winnipeg said if she could get rid of someone in paradise it would be Sam, to eliminate her competition for Cole Medders.  Last but not least, we found out that the Canadian cowboy, Joey Kirchner from Redcliff, Alta., had previous flings with both Nithisha Ketheeswaran from Stouffville, Ont., and Maria Garcia-Sanchez.  Quartney confronted Lisa about her kiss with Connor. But Lisa was adamant that she wants to get the full paradise experience, getting to know as many people as possible.  "I want a girl who knows what she wants," Quartney said. "It makes me want to step back a little bit.‚Äù  Cole Medders on Bachelor in Paradise Canada on Season 2, on Citytv  First Rose Ceremony  In the season's first Rose Ceremony, the men had the decisions to make, with many of them already unsure about the most rose-worthy singles.  The most complex was Cole, who found himself stuck between choosing Rianna Hockaday from The Bachelor Season 26, or Sam. Rianna continued to say throughout the episode that Cole was the only person she was attracted to in paradise.  Quartney still had some mixed feeling about Lisa, so he pursued a possibly connection with Maria from the first season of Bachelor in Paradise Canada, but he was shut down. Of course, Connor also spent some time with Maria.  Story continues  Joey and Shazeeda "Shaz" Gafoor from Toronto kept their relationship alive after last week's date, but he ended up kissing C√©line in the same night, giving him a hard choice to make.  Ultimately, here is how the Rose Ceremony turned out:  Austin Tinsley and Chelsea Vaughn  Matia Marcantuoni and Meagan Morris  Garrett Aida and Nithisha Ketheeswaran  Quartney Mixon and Lisa Mancini  Connor Brennan and Maria Garcia-Sanchez  Cole Medders and Sam Picco  Joey Kirchner and C√©line Paquette  Austin Tinsley and Chelsea Vaughn on Bachelor in Paradise Canada Season 2, on Citytv  Seemingly, the most secure relationship so far is between U.S. singles Austin Tinsley from The Bachelorette Season 17 and Chelsea Vaughn from The Bachelor Season 25.  The same can't be said for Lisa and Quartney, and Nithisha and Garrett.  Something new is always coming to paradise and this week, Godfrey Mangwiza from Big Brother Season 3 and Edward Naranjo from The Bachelorette Season 18 arrived on the beach to shake things up.  Godfrey ended up asking Lisa for a date and Edward asked Nithisha. It ended up being an ASMR-inspired double date, where the singles made sounds to each other.  The double date didn't sit well with both Quartney and Garrett. Things got particularly heated after Nithisha and Edward shared a kiss.  Lisa Mancini on Bachelor in Paradise Canada Season 2, on Citytv  Next week on 'Bachelor in Paradise Canada'  According to the teaser for next week's episode, Lisa continues to explore all her options in paradise, but there will be "serious consequences."  A new arrival is expected to shake things up for Cole and there's a special event that pits couples against each other, leaving some singles "out in the cold."

With the 2023 Atlantic hurricane season set to officially begin next month, Jamaicans are being urged to always be prepared for a storm.  The advice comes from Director of the Meteorological Service, Evan Thompson.  Speaking at the National Natural Disaster Risk Financing Policy Public Consultation, put on by the Ministry of Finance yesterday (May 16), Mr. Thompson reiterated the importance of preparedness, given Jamaica‚Äôs vulnerability. Meteorologist  Derek Sibley is a Certified Broadcast Meteorologist through the American Meteorological Society who joined the First Warn Weather team on June 28, 2021. Prior to joining the team, Derek was the Weekday Morning Meteorologist at KMID ABC Big 2 News/Fox 24 News in Odessa, Texas from April 2019 to May 2021. During his time in West Texas, Derek experienced and forecasted a handful of severe weather and winter weather. While with KMID, Derek was also a storm chaser for their Storm Interceptor vehicle and chased multiple severe thunderstorms and winter storms in West Texas. Before his time at KMID, Derek was a meteorologist for WeatherWorks in Hackettstown, New Jersey during the 2018-2019 winter season. During his time at WeatherWorks, Derek issued daily weather forecasts and weather alerts to many different clients across the east, northeast, and midwestern U.S. Derek is a graduate from the University of South Alabama where he earned his Bachelor of Science degree in Meteorology and a minor in Mathematics. He graduated in May of 2018. Before attending school, Derek interned at the National Weather Service and National Hurricane Center in Miami, Florida. Here he gained knowledge from experienced meteorologists and hurricane specialists. During his time with the National Weather Service, Derek collected weather data on frontal boundary passages through South Florida and shadowed the meteorologists. At the National Hurricane Center, he archived tropical cyclone information. Growing up in South Florida, Derek experienced a lot of meteorological phenomena. From sea breeze thunderstorms, to low pressure systems, to tropical weather, and even the occasional squall line from a cold front. However, it was the tropical storms and hurricanes that significantly elevated his interest into meteorology. During the 2004 and 2005 hurricane seasons, Florida was a hurricane landfall target. During that span, the state took a hit from 6 landfalls. While growing up in South Florida, Derek experienced 2 of those hurricanes that were a direct hit to his home. Hurricane Katrina was the first direct hit as a category 1 with winds of 75 mph on August 25, 2005. Hurricane Wilma was the second direct hit as a category 2 on October 24, 2005. After experiencing 2 record breaking hurricane seasons back-to-back, Derek fell in love with tropical meteorology and developed a passion for it. A passion so strong that he enjoys chasing hurricanes. Since then, Derek has chased some of nature‚Äôs most incredible hurricanes, including Matthew, Florence, Irma, and Michael, just to name a few. Hurricane Michael was Derek‚Äôs first category 5 hurricane which was in broad daylight, and a storm that he will never forget. You can check out Derek‚Äôs playlist of hurricane chasing via his YouTube channel. Derek also runs hurricaneconnect.com which is a website that is dedicated to the Atlantic Hurricane Season. Derek also enjoys chasing severe weather including tornadoes during the spring season. He‚Äôs chased in the central U.S. during the spring of 2012, 2016, and 2017. It was May 16, 2016, when Derek filmed his first tornado near Felt, Oklahoma. You can check out his severe weather footage on his YouTube channel. Aside from his life of weather and storm chasing, Derek enjoys going for long walks, swimming, playing video games, hanging out with friends, dining at restaurants, and of course, watching his Miami Dolphins. You can catch Derek weekday mornings on News 8 Now This Morning Monday-Friday from 5am-7am and from 12pm-12:30pm. Be sure to follow Derek on his social media pages at Meteorologist Derek Sibley on Facebook and @SibleyDerek on Twitter. You can also send Derek an email at dsibley@wkbt.com.

The radar is quiet this morning after some big thunderstorms moved across the area Monday evening. Temperatures are warm, and the air is sticky. Some fog formation is possible for a few hours ahead of sunrise this morning.  KATC Water Vapor Imagery May 16  A ridge of high pressure is currently centered over the Florida panhandle, extending westward into southeast Louisiana. A trough is digging across the Midwest and will continue drifting southeast. A front is draped across the ArkLaTex, and this front will slowly move southward across the area, eventually reaching the Gulf waters by Wednesday night. All of this will keep our area generally unsettled, with the chances for scattered showers and storms remaining in the 40-50% range for the next two days.  KATC Forecast Map for Tuesday Afternoon  Expect temperatures to climb to near 90 degrees this afternoon with heat index values around 95. Higher rain chances will be over central Louisiana, and eastern sections. Wednesday, we'll see the higher rain chances at the coast, while northern sections will start drying out. Highs Wednesday will hold in the upper 80s. Once the front moves offshore and washes out, some slightly cooler and drier air will be with us for Thursday and Friday with highs in the upper 80s and lows in the upper 60s.  KATC Rain Coverage for Tuesday selected cities.  Another front is expected to push in on Saturday with another chance for showers and storms. Saturday's front will have a better cool air mass behind it, so Sunday, and next week is looking great with sunshine and temperatures in the mid 80s.  KATC Ten Day Forecast  Even though we're still just over two weeks out from the start of hurricane season, there might be something to watch off the east coast late this week. Models are suggesting a surface low may spin along the cold front and push into the Atlantic waters off the Carolina coast. This wouldn't be unusual, as many of our "pre-season" systems have developed in this part of the world.  In case you missed it, the National Hurricane Center published last week that a system in January that developed off the northeast coast was indeed a "subtropical storm". Although this storm will remain unnamed, it will be considered the first "system" of the 2023 Hurricane Season. Therefore, if we get any development along the east coast, it will be designated "Tropical Depression #2", but if it gets a name, it'll still be Arlene.  National Hurricane Center Hurricane Names for the Atlantic Basin 2023-2028  If any of the names sound familiar, remember name lists are reused every sixth year, with some names retired, usually if they're major catastrophes. 2023's list is the same from the record setting 2005 hurricane season. The names Dennis, Katrina, Rita, Stan, and Wilma were all retired from 2005.
