The Carolina Hurricanes have had to navigate around some speed bumps on their road back to the Eastern Conference Final, where they will host the Florida Panthers in Game 1 at PNC Arena on Thursday (8 p.m. ET; TNT, CBC, SN, TVAS).  The Hurricanes have talked about taking the next step in the Stanley Cup Playoffs since being swept by the Boston Bruins in the 2019 conference final but could not win more than one series each of the past four postseasons. So what's been different this season?  "I think the biggest thing is we're getting contributions from everybody on our roster," general manager Don Waddell told NHL.com on Tuesday. "Everybody talks about the goal-scoring, and we lost some key guys, but we're finding a way to put the puck in the back of the net, and I think that's probably surprised a lot of people where the scoring is coming from."  Carolina is scoring 3.64 goals per game in the playoffs, which is up nearly half a goal from its regular-season average of 3.20, despite missing forwards Andrei Svechnikov (torn ACL), Max Pacioretty (torn Achilles tendon) and Teuvo Teravainen (broken hand). Those are three of Carolina's top six forwards.  [RELATED: Complete Hurricanes vs. Panthers series coverage]  Teravainen might return this round after being injured in Game 2 for the first round against the New York Islanders, but Svechnikov and Pacioretty haven't played in the playoffs and won't return until next season. So the Hurricanes will need more of what they've been getting from depth forwards such as Jordan Martinook, who had 10 points (three goals, seven assists) in five games in the second round against the New Jersey Devils, and Jesper Fast, who has eight points (five goals, three assists) in 11 playoff games, including two overtime goals.  "You can't rely on one, two, three guys to do it," Waddell said. "Our best players in our league play a third of the game. The other two thirds, you've got to find other people to be able to contribute. That's definitely been the reason."  In a Q&A with NHL.com, Waddell discussed Tervainen's potential return, moves he did and didn't make last offseason and before the 2023 NHL Trade Deadline, connections between the Hurricanes and Panthers and more.  Teravainen was cleared to practice with contact Monday. Could he be an option for Game 1 or some point later in the conference final?  "For sure. We're going to see how it goes in the next couple days and then make a decision on Thursday on how he's doing and if he's ready to go or needs a little more time. He's close, though. ‚Ä¶ When he had the surgery (April 20), they said it was going to be four weeks or so, which is now."  What does it say about coach Rod Brind'Amour and his staff to get complete buy-in from the players the way they have, considering the players you lost to injury?  "Since Rod took over, we built that culture in the locker room where, I think we were feeling sorry for ourselves for a couple of days when we lost Svechnikov, but then it's a proud locker room. There are 20 guys who want to go out and do the best they can every night and try to put us in position to win and that's what they've been doing."  Martinook said he was even surprised by his production after he had no points in the first round. Have you been surprised you got that kind of contribution from him and others throughout the first two rounds?  "You're happy for those guys because all these guys work so hard and maybe they're not natural scorers. So when the puck goes in for them, you feel good for them because you know what they put into it from effort and their work habits. So it's nice to see those kind of guys get rewarded."  The Hurricanes and the Panthers were not among the many teams in the Eastern Conference that made the big, splashy moves before the 2023 NHL Trade Deadline. You made depth moves by adding defenseman Shayne Gostisbehere from the Arizona Coyotes and forward Jesse Puljujarvi from the Edmonton Oilers. Was that by design?  "Every organization has different needs and different thoughts of how they're going to approach the trade deadline. Ours has always been that we try to build our team in the summers, so they can play together all year. There's no secret that we did try to do a few things that didn't work out. That's just the way things happen.  "We liked our team. We ended up with the second-best record in the NHL for a reason because we had pretty good depth and were consistent through the year. So we felt at the deadline, if we got one of the players that we wanted, great, but otherwise we were happy where we were."  Did not being able to pull off some of the trades you tried to make maybe turn out to be a good thing? Is there something to be said for not messing with chemistry so late in the season?  "That's the way Roddy is, too. He liked our team. We didn't want to give up anybody off our team, that's for sure, and that was probably one of the things that went against us in getting certain players. But you just never know how things are going to work out, and I've said all along, sometime the best trades you make are the ones that never happen."  Your big moves last offseason were to acquire defenseman Brent Burns in a trade with the San Jose Sharks and Pacioretty in a trade with the Vegas Golden Knights. Unfortunately, Pacioretty was injured, but has Burns given you what you hoped for?  "Yeah, [Burns] has done more than what any of us could ever expect him to do at 38. When we traded for him, he was here three days later buying a house, moved his family here and lived out of a motor home for six weeks while his house was getting ready. He was in the gym every day. When we did our testing, he was our second-best conditioned athlete at 37 years of age. So you knew he was all-in and committed and certainly he's done more than any of us could have expected on the ice and [been] a big part of our success for sure."  It was reported that the Hurricanes were in on Matthew Tkachuk before the Calgary Flames traded him to the Panthers last summer. How close did you get to making that trade?  "I don't like to name names, but we were involved in a couple of big trades last summer. I always tell people as much as you want to trade for players, you've got the other side that is going to do what they think is in the best interest of their franchise, which happened. That was a little bit more high profile, but every summer we probably try to make 10 trades that never happen, and you don't hear about those. My job as the general manager is always to try to make our team better and we try to do that in the summertime."  Frederik Andersen missed the playoffs last season with an injury, but is this how you envisioned your goalie tandem would work when signed Andersen and Antti Raanta in 2021?  "For sure. Freddie wasn't ready (in the first round because of illness and a minor injury) and Raanta grabbed it and won three of the first five games before Freddie came in in Game 6. Now, Freddie is running with it, but it doesn't matter. Whatever guy we have to go to or make the decision to play, we're very comfortable that the two we have can lead us where we want to get."  There are a lot of connections between the Hurricanes and Panthers, with former players in Florida (Eric Staal, Eetu Luostarinen, Gustav Forsling, Zac Dalpe), coach Paul Maurice and assistant Tuomo Ruutu, some members of management (assistant GM Paul Krepelka, senior adviser to GM Rick Dudley). Does that make the series interesting for you?  "I've got lots of good friends there, starting with (general manager) Billy Zito, but once the puck drops, we all know what our goals are. They're going to try to beat us and we're going to try to beat them You forget about those relationships while the game is going on, for sure, but there are a lot of ties between the two organizations."  And it's two teams from the old Southeast Division?  "Yeah, the old Southeast. Who would've ever thought that?"

Storyful  Four children who went missing for more than two weeks after the plane they were traveling in crashed in a jungle in Colombia were found alive, President Gustavo Petro said on Wednesday, May 17.The children ‚Äì aged just 13, 9, 4 and 11 months ‚Äì were found in thick jungle in Caqueta province, local media reported.The plane, a Cessna 206, was carrying seven people on a route between Araracuara and San Jose del Guaviare, and went missing on May 1, Colombia‚Äôs military said.El Tiempo reported that the two pilots of the plane and the children‚Äôs mother were found dead on May 16.Footage and images released by the Colombian Military Forces shows the downed aircraft, soldiers searching for the children with canines, as well as traces left behind by the children, such as a bottle and fruit peels.The military said its canine units were able to track an improvised shelter made by the children along with other elements that gave them clues to the trail of the missing minors. Credit: Colombian Military Forces via Storyful

As the North Atlantic hurricane season draws near, a new insurance sector report from Bloomberg Intelligence has raised concerns about the readiness of insurers to handle the increasing frequency and intensity of losses caused by flooding and climate change. The report emphasises a significant misalignment between pricing strategies and risk appetite among insurers. Notably, Munich Re and Swiss Re have been among the insurers experiencing insured losses surpassing $100 billion consecutively for three years.

The NHL‚Äôs final four is set, with the Panthers and Hurricanes kicking off the Eastern Conference final Thursday night, and the Stars and Golden Knights opening the Western Conference final Friday.  It‚Äôs not a conference-championship field many of us saw coming. In fact, none of the 41 members of The Athletic‚Äôs staff who voted in our second-round predictions correctly picked all four winners ‚Äî and only six had more than half.  Advertisement  Will the next round go a bit closer to expectations?  Here are our picks, with analysis, critique and some trolling from senior national writer Sean Gentille, national writer Hailey Salvian, analytics guru Shayna Goldman and NHL betting expert Jesse Granger.  Conference final predictions  Eastern Conference: Panthers vs. Hurricanes  Percent of vote Panthers Hurricanes 4 games 0.0% 0.0% 5 games 0.0% 4.9% 6 games 14.6% 39.0% 7 games 14.6% 26.8% Total 29.3% 70.7%  Gentille: More than 40 percent of the voters think this one is going seven games? I can‚Äôt tell if that‚Äôs a little or a lot.  Goldman: To me, that says we‚Äôre all projecting this to be a close series, which ‚Ä¶ can it please be after whatever we just saw in Round 2?  Granger: The Hurricanes are now the betting favorites to win it all at 2-to-1. That sound you hear is me running to catch back up to the bandwagon after falling off in March. I picked Carolina to win the Cup in the preseason and was on board all the way up until the injury to Andrei Svechnikov. The Canes have proven to be talented and deep enough to overcome that, and more.  Salvian: We all made so much about the injuries in Carolina that we forgot about (1) Rod Brind‚ÄôAmour and (2) how well this roster is built. That said, we all keep picking against Florida, and the Panthers just keep winning. It should be a fun one.  Western Conference: Stars vs. Golden Knights  Percent of vote Stars Golden Knights 4 games 0.0% 0.0% 5 games 2.4% 0.0% 6 games 31.7% 17.1% 7 games 34.1% 14.6% Total 68.3% 31.7%  Gentille: The overall number for the Stars feels right to me. I know they just had a seven-game series, but they‚Äôre really, really hard to pick against, especially if you think (as I do) that the Jason Robertson breakout is imminent.  Goldman: The Stars were one of the quietest contenders entering the postseason, so they absolutely deserve their moment here. But it is a bit wild that there isn‚Äôt a little more support behind a Vegas team that took a serious contender in the Oilers ‚Äî our staff‚Äôs top pick to win the Stanley Cup ahead of the first and second rounds. (Says, of course, someone who also picked the Stars here.)  Advertisement  Granger: I think it‚Äôs more than a bit wild that Dallas would get nearly 70 percent of the vote, especially considering Vegas is the betting favorite in this series (-140). Dallas did win all three regular-season matchups, but two came via shootout. After these teams were involved in plenty of high-scoring games in their previous series, I expect this one to be much more of a defensive chess match between coaches Bruce Cassidy and Pete DeBoer.  Salvian: I picked Dallas in seven, but Vegas looks like it‚Äôll be a really tough out. They‚Äôre a good five-on-five team with a mix of depth and star power. Adin Hill stepped in nicely after Laurent Brossoit was injured, but I do worry about their goalie luck a bit.  Beyond the third round  Stanley Cup champion  Gentille: With the benefit of hindsight, it seems that we, as a staff, were a little too far in on the Oilers.  Salvian: So ‚Ä¶ 65 percent of our staff chose the Leafs or Oilers to win the Cup before the second round began?  Goldman: Apparently it took two rounds of the Hurricanes crushing it, despite all of their injuries, for us to back them. The Panthers can‚Äôt seem to get that same respect, even after taking out Boston and Toronto.  Granger: The Panthers have the best two-round resume of any of these four teams and a red-hot goalie, but it‚Äôs still not enough to get more than a handful of votes.  Conn Smythe winner  Goldman: Pretty much every current Conn Smyth candidate besides Jake Oettinger wasn‚Äôt someone we expected to be here before the playoffs started. Among the players left, Matthew Tkachuk is still pretty low, but he (and the Panthers) don‚Äôt seem to have a problem with being underestimated.  Gentille: Someone else here predicted that Hintz would win the Conn Smythe way back at the start of this. I will not say whom.  Salvian: It was me. #HintzHive!  Advertisement  Granger: Take a look at what Jack Eichel‚Äôs doing in the first playoffs of his career. He leads Vegas with 14 points and is third of all players remaining, behind only Hintz (19) and Tkachuk (16). His play away from the puck has been even more impressive. The Golden Knights have outscored teams 10-4 with Eichel on the ice at even strength. If Vegas keeps winning, he‚Äôs the current favorite on the squad.  How have we done so far? Caribbean  School is almost out, and summer is nearly here. You want to visit the Caribbean, but you‚Äôre concerned about hurricanes. This fear is understandable, considering the terrifying strength of some hurricanes that have impacted the region.    No Caribbean hurricane has brought as much death and destruction as The Great Hurricane of 1780. According to History, since the storm predated modern storm-tracking technology, ‚Äúspecifics about its exact point of origin and strength are unknown.‚Äù However, the death toll is believed to have exceeded 20,000 people across several islands.    In 2017, Hurricane Irma brought howling winds, destroyed power lines, and caused flooding across Antigua, Barbuda, St. Barts, and St. Martin. Not long after was Hurricane Maria, which pummeled Puerto Rico and Dominica, among other islands.    Scientists believe climate change is largely at fault for these monster storms. NPR reported that climate change can intensify hurricanes and increase the chance of two or even three happening in rapid succession.    To be clear, there‚Äôs no such thing as a hurricane-free Caribbean island. However, if you visit any of these, you‚Äôll likely be safe.    Barbados    According to Forbes, ‚ÄúBarbados isn‚Äôt completely immune to hurricanes, but far fewer storms have hit this southern Caribbean nation than other islands.‚Äù    The island that used to be called Little England has pulled away to an extent. It became a republic in 2021 but remains part of the British Commonwealth.    As for tourism, Barbados exceeds expectations, with its glorious beaches, five-star resorts, and great golf opportunities. You can also take a tour of a rum distillery or enjoy the Crop Over Festival between May and August.    As for dining experiences, you‚Äôll be happy whether you opt for street food or a five-star, sit-down meal.    Aruba    The Dutch island of Aruba is less than 20 miles from the Venezuelan coast. This is relevant since, according to Trips To Discover, ‚Äúthe more south you go in the Caribbean, the less the odds are for a hurricane.‚Äù    Aruba is part of the ABC islands, alongside Bonaire and Cura√ßao. It is home to San Nicolas, the art capital of the Caribbean. Here, you‚Äôll find gorgeous, colorful murals that really bring life to the area.    Enjoy long walks on the beach and book accommodations at resorts such as the Aruba Marriott Resort and Casino, or Bucati and Tara Beach Resort, which is for adults only.    Trinidad and Tobago    Soca and calypso music were created in this dual island nation, and there‚Äôs plenty of both during carnival. Many Caribbean islands host carnival events, but it originated in Trinidad back in the 18th century.    Some of Trinidad‚Äôs best beaches include Maracas Bay, Las Cuevas Bay, and Macqueripe Bay, which is secluded.    There are options for adventure-seekers, too. You can do rock climbing at Pointe Gourde, explore Cumaca Cave, or go bike riding in Chaguaramas.    If you want to avoid the crowds, hop over to Tobago, where you can snorkel or swim in Nylon Pool. This natural, crystal-clear pool is in the middle of the ocean.    St. Lucia    If you haven‚Äôt been to St. Lucia, now is the time. Every inch of this magical island, from Soufri√®re all the way up to Gros Islet, looks like a painting.    Unwind at sulphur springs, also called the Caribbean‚Äôs ‚Äúdrive-in volcano.‚Äù Hike the Pitons with a guide or go zip-lining in Castries or Dennery. If you‚Äôre in Gros Islet on a Friday, don‚Äôt miss the street party. It‚Äôs a vibe!    As far as hurricanes, the Anse Chastanet Hotel gives some perspective.  ‚ÄúHistorically, only 14 hurricanes have moved within 60 miles of Saint Lucia since 1850. Of those, only one has been Category 4 and one has been Category 3. In the past 37 years, only one hurricane affected Saint Lucia directly, in 2010. In 2017, hurricane Maria as a category 2 storm, passed north of Saint Lucia with minimal impact. The risk of a hurricane hitting St. Lucia is the same as the risk in New York.‚Äù    Grenada    This southern-Caribbean island is at low risk for hurricanes. Hurricane Ivan in 2004 and Hurricane Emily in 2005 were the major exceptions in recent years, according to Islands.    Grenada, also called The Spice Isle, is known for cinnamon, cloves, ginger, and more. On Friday nights, set aside time for Fish Friday in Gouyave. This is a big draw for Grenadians and tourists. Not only is fish available, but many other kinds of seafood.    One afternoon, take in views of the boats at Prickly Bay Marina. There‚Äôs also Black Bay Beach, with its silky, dark sands. This is a great spot for swimming, walking, and, of course, flexing for the ‚ÄòGram.

Last fall‚Äôs Hurricanes Ian and Nicole missed upsetting last year‚Äôs nesting season for Florida‚Äôs coastal bird population by mere weeks, allowing for successful breeding for the original beach-front residents.  ‚ÄúWe breathe a retrospective sigh of relief that the year‚Äôs hurricanes came after nesting season,‚Äù said Audrey DeRose-Wilson, Audubon Florida‚Äôs director of bird conservation. ‚ÄúEven as we grieve with the coastal communities and inland neighborhoods still struggling to recover.‚Äù  Audubon Florida / Audubon Florida's Audrey DeRose-Wilson  Audubon Florida‚Äôs 2022 Coastal Report touted the successes of last year‚Äôs shorebird nesting season throughout the state‚Äôs regions, while also voicing fears about declines in future seasons due to carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases releases causing myriad changes on Florida shores.  Nesting success was particularly notable in Southwest Florida last year, when least terns raised 320 chicks including 19 at Big Marco Pass ‚Äî a first since 2019. Wilson‚Äôs plovers raised 41 chicks, black skimmers had 234 fledges, and a half-dozen snowy plover chicks made it through hatching and rearing until they had grown feathers and were capable of flight.  Gerald Herbert/ASSOCIATED PRESS / AP An American Oystercatcher is seen on the shore of the Chandeleur Islands, home of the Breton National Wildlife Refuge, is seen off the Southeastern coast of Louisiana Tuesday, April 27, 2010. A member of the species nested at Cayo Costa State Park in 2022, just narrowly missing the effects of Hurricane Ian.  Audubon Florida also helped create nesting habitat at Cayo Costa State Park that was the site of Lee County‚Äôs only successful American oystercatcher nest in years ‚Äì the spot was where Hurricane Ian made landfall four weeks after nesting season.  The report is the result of Audubon staff and volunteers keeping track of more than 300 shoreline nesting sites along the Gulf and Atlantic coasts. Nearly 600 volunteers spent at least 4,700 hours combined stewarding beach sites, monitoring bird colonies, and cleaning up fishing line and litter.  Hurricane Ian proved to be one of the most destructive storms in Florida‚Äôs history, devastating both coastal and inland communities along the southwest coast. A few short weeks later, Hurricane Nicole hit northeastern Florida ‚Äî a sure reminder that climate change will continue to bring stronger storms to our shores.  ‚Äî Audubon Florida‚Äôs 2022 Coastal Report  Hurricane, climate change fears  The avian-centered environmental group has fears that stronger hurricanes and worsening global warming will soon lead to far less successful nesting season for shoreline animals.  Hurricane Ian‚Äôs effects on Southwest Florida‚Äôs coastline may very well affect the current shorebird nesting season.  2022 Coastal Report /  Concerns revolve around altered beachlines, different water levels, changes in interior lakes and ponds on barrier islands, and red tide outbreaks that were a constant fixture in the region into the early weeks of this years nesting season.  Climate change-induced trends in seasonal rainfall patterns, including stronger and more frequent storms, will continue to negatively impact wading bird nesting, the report stated.  ‚ÄúWe will be paying special attention to hurricane-caused habitat changes in the 2023 nesting season,‚Äù DeRose-Wilson said. ‚ÄúAs we start another nesting season here on the coasts of Florida, the sea, shore, and wading birds that depend on our coastal areas are threatened by red tide, erosion, human disturbance, and more.‚Äù  Protecting the birds  Sea and shorebirds lay their eggs right on the sand, often in small divots creating nests that can‚Äôt be seen unless right over it.  The adult birds will flee when people or dogs get too close. And if constantly frightened away, the parents often abandon the colony and leave their nesting chicks to fend for themselves, which rarely ends well.  2022 Coastal Report /  Because of that, Florida Audubon and its volunteers rope off and often monitor important nesting areas, especially where threatened species are bunched up.  In Collier County, the Second Chance Critical Wildlife Area is now off-limits to boaters and will remain so through August 31. The shell island is at the south end of Cape Romano, south of Marco Island.  Second Chance won‚Äôt be the only one.  ‚ÄúPostings will be put up on Collier‚Äôs historically important nesting beaches, like Big Marco Critical Wildlife Area, Morgan Beach, and Dickman‚Äôs Point, in the coming weeks,‚Äù said Rochelle Streker, Audubon‚Äôs Southwest Florida shorebird program manager.  Environmental reporting for WGCUs funded in part by VoLo Foundation, a non-profit with a mission to accelerate change and global impact by supporting science-based climate solutions, enhancing education, and improving health.  Sign up for WGCU's monthly environmental newsletter, the Green Flash, today.  WGCU is your trusted source for news and information in Southwest Florida. We are a nonprofit public service, and your support is more critical than ever. Keep public media strong and donate now. Thank you.

Hurricane Dream, often a bridesmaid but never the bride in graded and group stakes competition, could be poised to reach the altar for the first time in the $200,000 Dinner Party Stakes (G3) on Saturday at historic Pimlico Race Course.  The 122nd running of the 1 1/8-mile Dinner Party for 3-year-olds and up on the grass will be the eighth of 10 stakes, six graded, worth $2.6 million in purses on a blockbuster 14-race program headlined by the 148th Preakness Stakes (G1), Middle Jewel of the Triple Crown.  Pimlico's oldest stakes race and the eighth-oldest in the country, the Dinner Party was contested at two miles for its 1870 debut, won by Hall of Famer Preakness. The distance has changed nine times over its history, returning this year to the current 1 1/8 miles for the first time since 2013 after being held the previous nine years at 1 1/16 miles.  Owned by Team Valor International and trained by Graham Motion, Hurricane Dream enters the Dinner Party off of an eye-catching 4 ¬Ω-length allowance win last month at Keeneland Race Course.  ‚ÄúHe's 6 years young,‚Äù Team Valor CEO Barry Irwin said of the French-bred gelding, which has made 20 starts. ‚ÄúWe've been very careful with him. He's the kind of horse, he's always thereabouts (among the top finishers). But he's never won a big one.‚Äù  Campaigned in France throughout the early part of his career, Hurricane Dream took part in 10 group stakes, finishing second four times with one third. He made his U.S. debut in January in the Pegasus World Cup Turf Invitational (G1) at Gulfstream Park, finishing 10th, beaten four lengths.  ‚ÄúHe didn't run badly,‚Äù Irwin said. ‚ÄúBut he never really got on track. So we sent him to Fair Hill (Training Center), backed off him and got him happy.‚Äù  The gelding followed that effort with his Keeneland win, which resulted in one of the highest Equibase speed figures (119) for any horse this year in a two-turn turf event.  ‚ÄúThe timing of this race is good, the distance is good, and he's sharp as a tack,‚Äù Irwin said.  One of the top contenders that Hurricane Dream will have to get past is Three Diamonds Farm's Atone, who was third after setting the pace in last year's Dinner Party and opened his 2023 campaign with a ¬æ-length win in the $1 million Pegasus World Cup Turf Invitational. Atone is trained by Michael Maker.  Eclipse Thoroughbred Partners' Speaking Scout, who was third to Atone in the Pegasus, is also entered in the Dinner Party for Motion, who will saddle three horses in the race.  WinStar Farm LLC and Siena Farm LLC's Emmanuel, who won the Canadian Turf Handicap (G3) at Gulfstream in March, is also expected to contest the Dinner Party. Todd Pletcher trains.  The other members of the projected 7-horse field include Courtlandt Farm's Never Explain (trainer Shug McGaughey), Russell Welch and Ran Leonard's Rising Empire (trainer Brandan Walsh) and Madaket Stables' Easter (Motion).

HURRICANE Andrew devastated Miami three decades ago - and has laid ruin to one of its most iconic sporting venues.  Miami Marine Stadium was declared unsafe in 1993 following the Category 5 storm and has sat abandoned ever since.  5 Miami Marine Stadium can be found looking out over Virginia Key Credit: AP  5 It was deemed unsafe for spectators after being battered by Hurricane Andrew in 1993 Credit: AP  5 The abandoned structure still stands and is a haven for animals and graffiti artists Credit: AP  Now, a $60million project is looking to breathe new life into the Magic City's forgotten powerboat racing arena.  Built in 1963, the 6,566-seat stadium can be found on Virginia Key, just off the Rickenbacker Trail out toward Key Biscayne.  Its steep single-deck stand looks out over the water and was the first purpose-built powerboat racing stadium ever constructed in the US.  Named Ralph Munroe Marine Stadium upon opening, it was designed by Cuban architect Hilario Candela and cost $2million.  With scenic views of Downtown Miami in the background, the stadium quickly became a fan favorite.  Watersports, boxing matches, music concerts, and even political rallies were held at the picturesque venue.  Eight huge concrete pillars support the huge canopy, allowing spectators an uninterrupted view of the bay from every seat.  But since Andrew made landfall in August 1992, the Miami Marine Stadium has laid dormant.  Since closing to the public, both the interior and exterior have proven to be a haven for graffiti artists and curious kids, with street art adorning the concrete walls at every turn.  Daring tourists often try to get a look inside the unsafe structure, which is guarded 24 hours a day by security.  After years of legal wrangling, the Miami Marine Stadium restoration project finally appears to be off the ground.  Expected to take at least two years, it will look to restore the stadium to its former glory.  Assistant communications director for the City of Miami Kenia Fallat explained: "To renovate the entire stadium, there would be much more work to do, structurally and otherwise."  The renovations are part of a huge upgrade to the whole Virginia Key area.  Work began in February, starting with partial pile repairs which could cost around $2.4million.  In 2012, the stadium was named a National Treasure by the National Trust.  And architect Richard Heisenbottle believes everything should be done to preserve and resurrect one of the country's forgotten jewels.  He said in 2021: "We can list all the reasons why we must support the Marine Stadium.  "The building is as much of our heritage as the freedom tower, Olympia Theatre, Vizcaya, and the Biltmore Hotel are.  "Yes, it is a different architectural style, but when we talk about saving a building like this, we talk about saving our heritage for future generations.  "What it takes is to have the political will to understand the importance of these things and to work toward making them financially viable.  "It is important and goes well beyond the financial aspects ‚Ä¶ but for the importance of the community."  5 A restoration project is hoping to restore the venue to its former glory Credit: Getty

Lions end Hurricane season with 2-1 heartbreaker  NEW RICHMOND ‚Äî Luke Abbott pitched New Richmond to a 2-1 win Tuesday over Wilmington in a Division II sectional baseball game at NRHS.  The Lions advance with a 15-12 record to meet No. 6 Fenwick 5 p.m. Thursday.  Wilmington‚Äôs season ends at 10-12.

After a 7-4 loss against the unranked Pittsburgh [Pitt] Panthers on Saturday, Miami baseball bounced back on Mother‚Äôs Day, winning 5-4 to secure the series at Charles L. Cost Field.  In the first inning, No. 11 Miami (34-17, 16-11 Atlantic Coast Conference (ACC)) started off strong, as it cashed in on a run in the first inning with the bases loaded. Pitt (22-27, 10-15 ACC) was quick to answer with two runs in the bottom of the first to give the home team the advantage early on.  Panthers pitcher Kyle Mosely was dominant, recording seven strikeouts through 4.1 innings. He was unable to silence third baseman Yohandy Morales, who batted speedy center fielder Jacoby Long in for a run to tie the game. Miami native Matthew Fernandez got a call from Pitt‚Äôs bullpen to try to rescue the inning as Morales and Kayfus occupied second and third with one out in the top of the fifth.  The top of the fifth did not end there, as outfielder Zach Levenson loaded the bases on a walk and second baseman Blake Cyr followed up with a powerful ground-rule double to give the ‚ÄòCanes a short-lived 4-2 lead.  Pitt counter-punched Miami‚Äôs three-run inning in the bottom of the sixth. Outfielder Kyle Hess put the Panthers in a great position to score by connecting on a triple to get the Pitt offense started. The Panthers scored two runs to tie the game, but almost as if it were a boxing match, Miami struck back.  Cyr and shortstop Dominic Pitelli recorded back-to-back singles. On the next at-bat, catcher Carlos Perez got hit by a pitch, loading the bases for the fourth time in the game. Pinch hitter Dorian Gonzalez hit a sac fly, which gave the Hurricanes a 5-4 lead in the top of the seventh.  The Hurricanes‚Äô infield had a remarkable offensive performance, with Cyr, Morales and Kayfus all getting on base at least three times.  Pitcher Andrew Walters also starred with a dominant pitching performance. The MLB prospect pitched 2.2 innings and struck out four batters while only allowing one hit.  Next up, the ‚ÄòCanes play their non-conference finale against Florida International on Tuesday before starting a series against Duke on Thursday at Mark Light Field in hopes of attaining a better seeding before the ACC Baseball Championship starts on May 23. The tournament will take place in Durham, North Carolina.

The new Hurricane Electric point of presence (PoP) at the DataVerge facility connects Tri-State area companies to the largest IPv6 backbone in the world, measured by number of connected networks.  IPv6 enables companies to stream multimedia seamlessly simultaneously to multiple destinations, increases the number of available IP addresses, and delivers faster connections by enabling more efficient packet processing.  It also provides increased security and performance for business-critical applications, such as support for customer billing and supplier relationships.  "Hurricane Electric is excited to establish a presence in DataVerge, our first in Brooklyn, to meet the demand for IP transit while providing a new resource to handle the growing bandwidth needs of established companies and the emerging start-ups that comprise DataVerge‚Äôs customer base,‚Äù said Mike Leber, president at Hurricane Electric.  ‚ÄúThe expansion will also offer increased redundancy to the diverse selection of network providers housed within the facility.‚Äù  In addition, Hurricane Electric‚Äôs presence provides DataVerge customers with direct access to improved load balancing, congestion management and fault tolerance by exchanging IP traffic with Hurricane Electric‚Äôs global network.  At the same time, Hurricane Electric‚Äôs network being established in DataVerge supports the expanding footprint for both companies in the surging Brooklyn and greater New York area.  ‚ÄúBy providing Hurricane Electric with its first point of presence in Brooklyn,‚Äù said Ray Sidler, CEO and Cofounder of DataVerge. ‚ÄúMore area enterprises and ISPs will benefit through the delivery of next generation IP connectivity solutions.‚Äù

When attending Erika Dickerson-Despenza‚Äôs latest play shadow/land, audiences soon discover that the play is named after a real place: Shadowland, which was a jazz dance hall and the first air-conditioned hotel for Black people in New Orleans. What audiences will not know is that Shadowland was a real place founded by Dickerson-Despenza‚Äôs great-grand uncle. As the playwright shares, ‚ÄúUncle Tony, who was actually my second cousin-once-removed, would tell me all these stories about it,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThere was this one postcard that guests would receive that was on sale on eBay for hundreds of dollars. He had a screenshot of it and every time he would talk, I would say, ‚ÄòCan you show me any pictures?‚Äô And he would say, ‚ÄòLost them in the floods.‚Äô‚Äù It was Tony‚Äôs grandfather who founded the real-life Shadowland at 1921 Washington Avenue‚Äîa detail revealed in the play, currently playing an extended run at Off-Broadway‚Äôs The Public Theater through May 28.  Shadow/land is the first in a decalogy of works (not all of which are plays) that Dickerson-Despenza is writing about Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath. The play follows mother and daughter Magalee and Ruth, two adult Black women living in New Orleans who have inherited Shadowland, a jazz dance hall and hotel. (And like the real-life Shadowland, there is also a real-life Ruth and Magalee.) On their way to the Superdome where they plan to take shelter as Hurricane Katrina‚Äôs landfall looms, they stop by the bar to grab Magalee‚Äôs bag‚Äîonly to become trapped by the storm. Over six days, mother and daughter try to survive as the flood waters rise around them and the streets become body-filled rivers. Shadow/land stars Lizan Mitchell as Magalee, Joniece Abbott-Pratt as Ruth, and Christine Shepard as Grand Marshal.  Though Chicago-born and raised, Dickerson-Despenza has deep roots in New Orleans through her father‚Äôs side‚Äîroots that can be traced as far back as the late 1700s. Compelled to keep digging into the real Shadowland, Dickerson-Despenza turned to social media, in particular a Facebook group called ‚ÄúOld New Orleans ‚Äì ‚ÄòBlack‚Äô In the Day.‚Äù There‚Äôs a lot of community elders and people with roots in New Orleans, including people who witnessed Katrina firsthand, in the private group. ‚ÄúUncle Tony was telling me how the Despenzas were something and they were a name. I was like, ‚ÄòOh, he just wants you to feel good about our family line.‚Äô I decided to just write in this group. I was like, ‚ÄòLet me see if people remember this place called Shadowland.‚Äô And there were so many comments from people,‚Äù she reveals.  People began replying, remembering growing up across the streets from Shadowland, popping in to see singers and musicians, wondering who owns the property since the music hall burned down in the 1980s. Heartened by the outpouring of response, Dickerson-Despenza thought maybe she‚Äôd get to see photos of the place. But it wasn‚Äôt to be. ‚ÄúWhen I asked for pictures, everyone said, ‚ÄòLost in the flood.‚Äô‚Äù    While there have been many times New Orleans has flooded, there‚Äôs one storm that continues to leave a mark on the Crescent City and its communities: Hurricane Katrina. ‚ÄúIt was my desire to excavate this last cultural institution and the people who lived it. I don't want it to be lost. We‚Äôre still in the afterlife of Katrina,‚Äù tells Dickerson-Despenza. She dedicates the play to Ruth, Magalee, and Victor Despenza (an ancestor mentioned in the play). She also dedicates it to the almost 2,000 people who died during Katrina and in the floods, and the 25,000 refugees who were displaced to Houston‚Äôs Astrodome. The names of the victims cover the entrance to the theatre at The Public and parts of the set.  ‚ÄúThere was so much talk about the loss of homes, which was great and important to talk about.‚Äù But there‚Äôs another conversation that the playwright wants people to discuss: What it means for Black communities to lose cultural institutions, and historical artifacts, like the photos of Shadowland. ‚ÄúI have an elder cousin who holds the deed to that land. So the land, as far as I know, is still in the family. I'm still very proud of that,‚Äù Dickerson-Despenza explains. ‚ÄúBut, I am sad that the institution no longer exists, that very few people know about it.‚Äù In writing the play, Dickerson-Despenza is ‚Äútrying to recover this piece of history.‚Äù  Before Katrina, Black Americans comprised about two-thirds of New Orleans‚Äô population, and like in all Black communities, the importance of having and keeping cultural institutions is paramount. But in the play, Ruth wants to sell Shadowland to a developer. Meanwhile, Magalee believes Ruth should care more about protecting her inherited legacy. She reminds Ruth of how Ruth‚Äôs great-great-great-great-grandmother was taken from Saint-Dominigue and sold as a slave in New Orleans. She worked to someday ‚Äúbuy her own self‚Äù and be free from slavery; and then she bought the land and founded Shadowland, which has been passed down since.  What to do with Shadowland is only one of the tensions between Ruth and Magalee. They reflect on how they‚Äôve faced racism differently, argue over Ruth‚Äôs sexuality, and disagree over exactly how to handle Magalee‚Äôs failing memory. Dickerson-Despenza's play and its characters have a political bent to them because it is intensely personal. She writes ‚Äúpeople in place,‚Äù and politics inherently come with the lived experiences of her characters ‚Äúin their bodies and in geographical space. Their lived experiences help them to develop and sustain politics around that experience,‚Äù she explains. ‚ÄúI think the best political creative writing is that which centers the people.‚Äù    In her work to center people and their lived experiences, Dickerson-Despenza honors her ancestors. ‚ÄúWriting is a spiritual practice for me,‚Äù she shares. ‚ÄúI have all kinds of family buried in New Orleans, some very close to my home. I am in steady conversation with my ancestors. There are things that I asked about like, ‚ÄòWhat do you all need?‚Äô And that's a part of the creation.‚Äù Remember that great-great-great-great-grandmother Rosaline who Magalee says founded Shadowland? There‚Äôs a real Rosaline in Dickerson-Despenza‚Äôs family tree.  Quoting 20th century philosopher Walter Benjamin who said, ‚ÄúTo articulate the past historically does not mean to recognize it ‚Äòthe way it really was.‚Äô It means to seize hold of a memory as it flashes up in a moment of danger,‚Äù Dickerson-Despenza blends the facts of her family‚Äôs stories, and so many other stories, with fiction to try and capture the truth of the past.  Before shadow/land began its world premiere, The Public presented the world premiere of Dickerson-Despenza‚Äôs cullud wattah in fall 2021. The Afro-surrealist play follows five Black women from across three generations of a family all living through the Flint, Michigan water crisis. The play ends by reminding the audience that many homes in Flint still do not have clean water. Says Dickerson-Despenza, ‚ÄúThe media moves so fast onto the next tragedy or next headline that we forget. I‚Äôve had people literally say to me about Flint and about Katrina, ‚ÄòI didn‚Äôt know it was that bad.‚Äô‚Äù  The two plays, similar in the themes explored and the playwright‚Äôs experimentations across genre and medium, form the foundation which Dickerson-Despenza intends to expand upon in the Katrina decalogy. Originally billed as 10 plays, the series will now be 10 works, including museum work. One of the plays will explore what happened when emergency calls were re-routed to Baton Rouge after the Orleans Parish call center flooded‚Äîand the emotional labor involved in being on the other end of the line as people plead for help first, and to not die alone second. Another follows characters that are talked about, but never seen, in shadow/land three months after the play as the traumas from Katrina continue to haunt them.  Across all of it, Dickerson-Despenza‚Äôs guiding hope for herself as an artist is to be a ‚Äúdelicate sculptor of horror,‚Äù a moniker given to Harlem Renaissance Black female sculptor Meta Vaux Warrick Fuller. ‚ÄúNot for sensationalism‚Äôs sake,‚Äù she clarifies, ‚Äúbut to really bring certain things to the forefront of our cultural memory so that we remember ourselves and each other in that process.‚Äù It‚Äôs fitting, then, that on the back wall of the shadow/land set is a photo of the real Ruth and Magalee in formal attire, taken in the ballroom of Shadowland. ‚ÄúWe added a picture of my Uncle Tony that I took as the last photo I took of him before he passed,‚Äù Dickerson-Despenza shares. It‚Äôs a tribute to the ancestors of shadow/land, to make sure they are not forgotten.  Check out photos from shadow/land at The Public below.

TAMPA, Fla. (WFLA) ‚Äî The first tropical wave of the season emerged off the coast of Africa on Monday morning, according to the National Hurricane Center.  The NHC said the wave is the first of about 60 that are generated over North Africa each year.  ‚ÄúThe GFS model has been suggesting we watch the waters off the SE U. S. Coast in about 10 days for tropical development. This is too far in the future to put much stock in, but would be seasonally appropriate,‚Äù Jeff Masters, a former hurricane scientist tweeted.  With hurricane season just weeks away, the NHC has begun its daily Tropical Weather Outlook for the Atlantic basin. The outlook will be issued at 2 a.m., 8 a.m., 2 p.m., and 8 p.m.  Researchers at Colorado State University believe this season could be slightly below-average.  In April, researchers released their prediction of the 2023 Atlantic hurricane season. They believe it will feature 6 hurricanes ‚Äî two of them Category 3, 4, or 5 hurricanes ‚Äî and 13 named storms.  Hurricane season runs from June 1 to Nov. 30.  This season‚Äôs potential hurricane names include Arlene, Bret, Cindy, Don, Emily, Franklin, Gert, Harold, Idalia, Jose, Katia, Lee, Margot, Nigel, Ophelia, Philippe, Rina, Sean, Tammy, Vince, and Whitney.

By Dom Luszczyszyn, Shayna Goldman and Sean Gentille  The Carolina Hurricanes are a deep team with a hard-nosed style built for the postseason ‚Äî and one of the best defensive teams in the league.  The Florida Panthers are a star-studded team with a hard-nosed style built for the postseason ‚Äî and one of the best offensive teams in the league.  Advertisement  It‚Äôs a battle between two former Southeast Division rivals, two teams with similar stylistic tendencies but dueling ideologies towards roster construction. One is built on depth and defensive structure. One is built on stars and offensive chaos.  The Hurricanes and Panthers are twin flames ready to ignite ‚Äî the end result should be an epic and explosive clash of a series. Carolina and Florida were built for this moment: a date with the Stanley Cup earned by a series that could truly go in either direction.  The Odds  The difference in this series? Home-ice advantage and Teuvo Teravainen. That‚Äôs how close these two teams are. Without Teravainen Carolina‚Äôs chances of beating Florida at home are 55 percent and Florida‚Äôs chances of beating Carolina at home are 55 percent. Teravainen‚Äôs return adds one percentage point per game adding to Carolina‚Äôs slight edge from having one extra home game.  Whether you actually want to believe that in these playoffs where home teams have won only 43 percent of the time is up to you, but historically home-ice advantage in the playoffs is actually larger. It‚Äôs especially interesting between these two teams given what they‚Äôve each managed during this postseason. The Hurricanes are 5-1 at home, but the Panthers are 6-1 on the road. Immovable object ‚Äî meet unstoppable force.  Some may be surprised the Panthers have made it this far and are now in a coin-flip series to make the Cup Final, but as we‚Äôve warned all postseason the Panthers are not your average wild-card team. They came into the playoffs with the fifth-highest Net Rating and were only underdogs because they had to face the two teams that ranked first and second.  Florida has survived an extremely tough path, but the road ahead doesn‚Äôt get much easier against a defensive equal. Carolina has the lower Net Rating, but the two teams end up with a near equal expected win percentage due to Carolina‚Äôs defensive superiority.  Advertisement  Which team comes through? That all depends on which team‚Äôs strengths shine brightest ‚Äî and which team‚Äôs weaknesses are exposed less.  The Numbers  The series is a matchup of a team with one of the best offensive ratings (plus-62) against one of the best defensive teams (plus-35).  At five-on-five, these were two of the top offensive generators in the league, separated by just .03 expected goals for per 60. Neither team capitalized on their chances to match their scoring chances, though Florida had a clear edge in actual goal scoring with stronger priors.  Defense is where these two really split in the regular season, as the Canes were the stoutest team in their own end while the Panthers were in the bottom third of the league. Florida didn‚Äôt have as consistent goaltending to match, either.  Through two playoff rounds, Carolina‚Äôs maintained their edge as one of the best five-on-five teams in the league with a high rate of scoring chances, and a lot of scoring despite some key injuries. While they had a slight advantage in limiting scoring chances against, Florida conceded fewer goals to this point.  Special teams make for an intriguing matchup here. Neither team had the most dangerous power play in the regular season. Florida created chances, but couldn‚Äôt convert. Carolina generated less, with even fewer goals to show for it. The story has been the same for the Canes in the playoffs. Florida, on the other hand, improved ‚Äî and a change in formation, going to four forwards and one defenseman instead of having two blueliners on the top unit, helped that. Their power play still wasn‚Äôt the most prolific, but actually matched what they created on the scoresheet.  The challenge, of course, is managing to generate anything on the power play against the Hurricanes. Their power kill has been a part of their identity as a disruptive short-handed unit. The Islanders and Devils, who both had regular-season issues on the advantage as well, struggled to score on the power play against Carolina‚Äôs aggressive play which neutralized their opponents through two rounds with three goals for, and only three against.  Advertisement  Florida‚Äôs penalty kill has allowed a higher rate of quality looks and goals against this postseason. If that continues, maybe it opens the door to power-play success for the Canes.  The Big Question  Can Sergei Bobrovsky keep being the $10 million man?  Here‚Äôs a highly unscientific prediction: If you were to ask 10 different hockey fans what ‚ÄúPlayoff Bob‚Äù means to them, you‚Äôd get five people saying, ‚Äúyep, I‚Äôd take that guy‚Äù and five vigorous head shakes. There certainly wouldn‚Äôt be a consensus.  Nor should there be, really. Bobrovsky, even compared to general volatility at the goaltender position, has one of the more bizarre careers on record. He couldn‚Äôt establish himself as a starter early in his career with the Flyers, then made five All-Star teams in seven years and won two Vezinas with the Blue Jackets. The capstone for him in Columbus was a .925 save percentage postseason run in 2019 that featured a stunning sweep of the top-seeded Tampa Bay Lightning. Until that year, he‚Äôd put up an .891 save percentage and five wins in 24 playoff games.  That series against the Lightning, featuring the emergence of good ‚ÄúPlayoff Bob,‚Äù combined with his generally strong play over the previous seven seasons earned him the third-biggest goalie contract of all time ($70 million for seven years) and some dialed-up expectations with the Panthers. In the four ensuing seasons, he‚Äôs been uneven. Not many goalies are capable of living up to the price tag ‚Äî it‚Äôs not an economically wise spot to spend that much cap space ‚Äî but Bobrovsky hasn‚Äôt been a full-fledged disaster, either. Year-by-year, his save percentages are .900, .906, .913 and .901. That‚Äôs passable, but not what $10 million goaltending looks like.  Part of the weirdness for Bobrovsky thus far in Florida has been the presence of a series of backups who‚Äôve seemed capable, if not destined, to take his job. Chris Driedger (.938 save percentage, 7.36 GSAx in 2019-20) wound up as a priority for the Kraken in the expansion draft. Spencer Knight was an elite prospect and, though he entered the player assistance program in February, is still just 22. Alex Lyon took over for an ill Bobrovsky at the end of the regular season and only gave the net back after dragging the Panthers into the playoffs. It was the right call; Lyon was hot, and Bobrovsky had gone .899 in 17 playoff games with the Panthers, winning just six of them. That‚Äôs bad ‚ÄúPlayoff Bob.‚Äù  Paul Maurice, though, made the switch back to Bobrovsky relatively early in their first-round series against the Bruins ‚Äî at the end of a Game 3 loss that put Boston up 2-1 ‚Äî and he‚Äôs been outstanding. Since allowing five goals to the Bruins in Game 4, Bobrovsky has put up a .928 save percentage, just one game with a save percentage under .917, and a playoff-best 8.81 goals saved above expected. Second place in GSAx in that span? Carolina‚Äôs Freddie Andersen with a 3.6. That‚Äôs what $10 million goaltending looks like.  Advertisement  Now, whether he can keep it up is anyone‚Äôs guess. In February and early March, he had a .930 run in 12 starts. From March 8, on, he went .871 in eight games. That split says it all. Plus, this is ‚ÄúPlayoff Bob‚Äù we‚Äôre talking about. Anything is possible.  The X-Factor  How much more oomph does Jordan Martinook have left in him?  Turns out that the pop Carolina needed in its lineup was on the roster all along, in the form of a 30-year-old who was made available on waivers in October. The Hurricanes gambled that Martinook‚Äôs $1.8 million AAV would be too steep for contenders and too pricey for budget teams, and they were correct.  First, Martinook put up the best regular season of his career, setting a career-high with 34 points, scoring 11 five-on-five goals on nearly 17 expected and playing a major part on a difference-making third line with Jordan Staal and Jesper Fast. Carolina‚Äôs five-on-five dominance, in plenty of ways, starts with them.  Martinook has leveled up in the postseason, leading Carolina in their Round 2 series against New Jersey in five-on-five individual scoring chances (14), individual high-danger chances (eight), shots (10), points (seven) and assists (five). He‚Äôs also carrying a five-game point streak.  Would it be smart to predict that Martinook himself keeps shooting better than 27 percent, as he did against the Devils? Probably not. He was at 7.33 for the regular season. What about Carolina‚Äôs overall on-ice shooting percentage of 21.2? That‚Äôs likely to drop, too. If it does, though, Martinook has already done his part. Now, it‚Äôll likely be up to one of Carolina‚Äôs other pace-controlling forwards to heat up at the right time. Someone needs to turn those chances into goals, whether it‚Äôs Martinook or someone else.  The Rosters  Offensive and Defensive Rating explainer  Advertisement  The same storyline that‚Äôs surrounded the Hurricanes through the first two rounds continues into the Eastern Conference finals. Carolina‚Äôs without a lot of star power and finishing talent. Up front, they have just one healthy star in Sebastian Aho who has a plus-11 rating. Compare that to Florida, who has three forwards with matching or higher offensive ratings ‚Äî Carter Verhaeghe (plus-11), Aleksander Barkov (plus-15), and Matthew Tkachuk (plus-27).  Aho‚Äôs coming into the third round with five goals and five assists through 11 games. Carolina‚Äôs generated the majority of the shots and chances in his five-on-five minutes, and outscored opponents 9-3. Matching up against Nico Hischier in Round 2 proved to be a bit more of a challenge, though. In 30 minutes head-to-head, the Devils had the edge in shot attempts (32-21) and scoring chances (13-8) without the goals to show for it.  Now, Aho will likely see a lot of Barkov and Verhaeghe across the way. That‚Äôs a challenge to contain because by the numbers, Aho with Stefan Noesen and Seth Jarvis doesn‚Äôt match up to the Panthers‚Äô top line that has Anthony Duclair rounding out the trio. The return of Teravainen should help, but there‚Äôs still a wide disparity.  Barkov has netted two goals and nine points through 12 games this postseason, and has fallen below break-even in expected goals at five-on-five. That‚Äôs more so from the first half of the postseason, in his matchup with Brad Marchand which was a challenge. Against Toronto, Barkov saw a lot of Mitch Marner and Auston Matthews and managed to maintain the edge in quality chances and keep the Maple Leafs scoreless in that time.  His linemate, Verhaeghe, has been scoring at a point-per-game pace and comes up clutch in big moments for his team. He thrives in transition, and always comes to play this time of year. No one in Florida has had a better influence on the Panthers‚Äô goal-scoring than Verhaeghe, who has increased it by 1.65 goals per 60.  Duclair, the third member of that line, took a few games to get back on the scoresheet this postseason. But to this point in their almost 113 minutes of play, they‚Äôre only generating 43 percent of the expected goals share. They did, however, have the clear edge in scoring in that time.  The second line is where the two teams really depart and much of that has to do with Tkachuk, who had an MVP-caliber season that‚Äôs carried into the playoffs. Even when the winger wasn‚Äôt on the scoresheet last series, he was physical and kept the ice tilted in his minutes. Few players had as strong of an impact on their team‚Äôs five-on-five expected and actual goal-scoring in the regular season, and he continues to be among the best this postseason for the Panthers.  Alongside Sam Bennett and Nick Cousins, that line has combined for a 58 percent expected goals rate.  Carolina‚Äôs second line is composed of three players with defensive strengths, but less offensive upside between Martinook, Jesperi Kotkaniemi, and Fast. But in Round 2, these players were coming up big on the scoresheet. The big question is whether that can continue since it‚Äôs not a part of any of their identities ‚Äî and if it can keep pace with Florida‚Äôs trio across the way.  It‚Äôll probably be Staal‚Äôs job to contain Tkachuk and his line, after taking on a lot of Mathew Barzal and Jack Hughes to this point. In his most recent series against Hughes, Staal earned more than 60 percent of the shot and expected goals share at five-on-five, and helped the Canes outscore New Jersey 3-0. Martin Necas can add some scoring to that line, but the task is for Jack Drury to keep up if they match up to Florida‚Äôs top offensive line.  While Florida has the clear edge in forward strength at plus-31 to Carolina‚Äôs plus-nine, Carolina‚Äôs rating is almost double Florida‚Äôs on defense.  Jaccob Slavin and Brent Burns lead the way for the Canes, who have rocked a 60.5 percent expected goals rate through two rounds. They‚Äôve dominated their opponents on the scoresheet, outscoring them 13-3 at five-on-five so far. That duo‚Äôs offensive rating is actually matched by Aaron Ekblad‚Äôs and Gustav Forsling‚Äôs across the way ‚Äî they just aren‚Äôt nearly as stout in their own zone.  Carolina‚Äôs second pair has a more balanced approach between Brady Skjei and Brett Pesce, but after a strong regular season, they‚Äôve slowed down so far this postseason. This is the duo that shares the workload of going up against top competition with Slavin and Burns, and it likely won‚Äôt be any easier this series since Florida has their two best offensive threats split out between their top six.  Florida has the best offensively-rated defenseman on their second pair in Brandon Montour. But it‚Äôs an imbalanced duo with Marc Staal at his side.  The third pair is a bit more closely matched, but the Canes once again had the edge here on paper. For Florida, Josh Mahura and Radko Gudas have elevated their game this postseason with good two-way play and the results to match.  Back in goal, Florida has the hotter goalie now that Bobrovsky‚Äôs saved 9.32 goals above expected through five games. Whether he can keep that up remains to be seen, or if Lyon can step back up if needed. If he can, that may be key against a team without as much finishing talent as a contender could want.  Carolina, on the other hand, has three options to choose from between Andersen, Antti Raanta, and Pyotr Kochetkov. All three have appeared in a playoff game so far, but right now the starting net belongs to Andersen who has saved 5.48 goals above expected through six games after slotting in for Game 6 against the Islanders. These netminders have a lot of support between the Canes‚Äô aggressive forecheck and strong defense that trickles down the entire lineup. That gives them a bit more security in net even though their opponent has the goaltender coming in hot.  The Key Matchup  Sebastian Aho vs. Aleksander Barkov  It‚Äôs not just the pride of the former Southeast Division at stake ‚Äî it‚Äôs also the pride of Finland. Barkov and Aho are two of the best Finnish players in the game and will likely see a lot of each other head-to-head with Staal in charge of the Tkachuk assignment. A true power vs. power matchup.  Going into the playoffs that matchup would lean in Barkov‚Äôs favor. The former Selke Trophy winner offers a bit more defensive upside and has the obvious offensive oomph advantage too. The two players score a similar amount, but Barkov‚Äôs playmaking is on another level. Aho is great, but it‚Äôs hard to imagine many people choosing him over Barkov.  During the playoffs, it‚Äôs been the opposite story. Aho has one more point in one fewer game with eight of his 10 coming at five-on-five. Barkov, in contrast, has just three at even strength and on a per-60 basis it‚Äôs not close at all: 3.41 for Aho and 0.99 for Barkov. That also extends to each player‚Äôs ability to drive play with Carolina earning 58 percent of the expected goals while outscoring opponents 9-3. With Barkov on the ice, Florida has been out-chanced with 47 percent of the expected goals with an even scoreline.  It‚Äôs been an unusually rough playoffs for Barkov and if that continues, that tilts the scales further towards Carolina in what should be a close series. Florida‚Äôs captain needs to show up and win this matchup ‚Äî something that‚Äôll be very tough with the way Aho is playing.  The Bottom Line  Series this tight often come down to a single storyline. Maybe Carolina‚Äôs depth forwards continue contributing enough goals to keep things on track. Maybe Bobrovsky is the eraser in another four Florida wins. Maybe, maybe, maybe.  Those tiny margins, combined with all those ideological differences we just discussed, give this matchup serious potential. Don‚Äôt sleep on the entertainment value. After all, nothing makes for better TV than a Game 7 ‚Äî and that seems like our potential destination here. Either way, the winner will deserve it. By JADE RUSSELL  Tribune Staff Reporter  jrussell@tribunemedia.net  RESIDENTS of Abaco are wasting no time preparing for the hurricane season as the memories of Hurricane Dorian‚Äôs horror still linger.    Last week, Bahamas Department of Meteorology Acting Director Jeffrey Simmons advised Bahamians to prepare for the hurricane season, noting forecasters predicted 13 named storms for the year.    ‚ÄúThis year for 2023, the prediction is now out for 13 named storms, six of them to become hurricanes and two of them to become major hurricanes, category 3 and above,‚Äù Mr Simmons said at an Office of the Prime Minister press conference.    North Abaco Chief Councillor D‚ÄôAngelo Edgecombe told The Tribune work had already started on one of the island‚Äôs hurricane shelters.    ‚ÄúLast week I had a mechanic come to Coopers Town‚Äôs hurricane shelter,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúHe would have looked at the generator there and he would have put together a service list for the generator.‚Äù  Mr Edgecombe said preparations are ‚Äúwell underway‚Äù at this moment. He noted officials do not want to wait until the last minute to ensure emergency supplies, shelters, and operations are in place.    Abaco was ravaged when Hurricane Dorian struck the island on September 1, 2019.  Mr Edgecombe said the trauma of Dorian is still challenging for many residents.  Some Abaconians have decided to leave the island temporally if a major Hurricane was forecast to hit Abaco.    ‚ÄúI‚Äôve spoken with a few people and in the event after monitoring the hurricane if it was to come, they probably will make the decision to leave the island rather than stay this time,‚Äù he said.    The chief councillor said homeowners have started putting up their hurricane shutters while others have stocked up on food, gas, and other items.    Another resident, Drexel Bootle, said his house was destroyed by the massive surges of Dorian, with water rising to the ceiling.  ‚ÄúWe had to get the house and start from scratch only the frame was here. Thank God I had a little 50 percent insurance,‚Äù he said.  Mr Bootle has been able to rebuild the majority of his home.  During the reconstruction of his house, he made hurricane safety adjustments.  ‚ÄúWhen we started the repairs, everything I did. I was doing well, if a hurricane happens again this is what I‚Äôm going to do,‚Äù he said.    Meanwhile, Crystal Williams said the high cost of living has made it difficult for residents to adequately prepare for hurricane season.    Ms Williams said: ‚ÄúPersons are strained by the uncontrollable high prices of food, gas, and everyday essential items. The government isn‚Äôt even prepared, the promised shelter is not even out of the ground. So, I‚Äôm sure that persons will take needed measures to protect their estates and well being.‚Äù

Holly Beach, LA (KPLC) - Public restrooms built to withstand hurricane-force winds are in the works for Holly Beach.  The pre-cast concrete restrooms on the Creole Nature Trail are being funded with a $113,160 National Scenic Byways grant through the Federal Highway Administration and a 20 percent match from the Creole Nature Trail Scenic Byway District, according to information from Visit Lake Charles.  The Cameron Parish Police Jury, along with the Johnson Bayou Recreation District, will provide property for the restrooms as well as water, electricity, utilities, permits, and maintenance.  ‚ÄúThe wildlife, outdoor experiences, beaches, birding, and coastal excursions along the Creole Nature Trail have been available for visitors since the storms of 2020; however, essential facilities, such as public restrooms, have made it more of a challenge for visitors wanting to spend the day exploring. We are grateful for this opportunity to address public necessities at Holly Beach,‚Äù said Shelley Johnson, chair of the Creole Nature Trail District Board of Commissioners.  Visit Lake Charles also says the Cameron Prairie National Wildlife Refuge Visitors‚Äô Center will reopen from 10 a.m. until 2 p.m. Saturday. Regular hours of operation will be from 9:30 a.m. until 2:30 p.m. Tuesday through Thursday.  For more about the Creole Nature Trail, visit www.creolenaturetrail.org.  Copyright 2023 KPLC. All rights reserved.

VOLUSIA COUNTY, Fla. ‚Äî Southeast Volusia Habitat for Humanity, State Farm and students from Embry Riddle University will be handing out free hurricane prep kits Saturday in New Smyrna Beach.  State Farm also announced Monday that it is donating $18,750 as part of its Good Neighbor program to repair five homes in Volusia County that were damaged by hurricanes.  What You Need To Know Southeast Volusia Habitat for Humanity, State Farm volunteers and students from Embry Riddle University will be handing out hurricane prep kits Saturday      The kits will be distributed from 10 a.m. until noon at Old Fort Park in New Smyrna Beach    State Farm also announce Monday that it was donating $18,750 to fund home repairs in the county  In a press release, State Farm said the grant is part of a long-term recovery effort.  ‚ÄúSEV Habitat for Humanity will use the funds awarded by State Farm to support five home repair projects through SEV Habitat for Humanity‚Äôs Disaster Recovery Program, which includes the purchase of tools and equipment,‚Äù stated State Farm.  Last year, Volusia County and other parts of the state were slammed by hurricanes Ian and Nicole. This resulted in damaged homes, businesses, and property. The combined storms resulted in billions of dollars worth of damage.  The hurricane prep kits will be handed out by Embry Riddle University students and volunteers from Habitat for Humanity and State Farm from 10 a.m. until noon Saturday at Old Fort Park in New Smyrna Beach.

PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla. ‚Äî Nearly eight months after Hurricane Ian ravaged Southwest Florida, some homeowners say their insurance company won‚Äôt pay for the full cost of repairs and they are left with no option but to sue.  ‚ÄúThis is the shell of our beautiful home‚Ä¶ last year after the hurricane,‚Äù Sherry McBride said with a shaky voice as she stood next to her husband, Jim.  ‚ÄúWe are in our 70s. He's a Vietnam veteran, and we‚Äôre hurting right now.‚Äù  Hurricane Ian ripped through the McBride‚Äôs neighborhood in Port Charlotte, leaving their three-bedroom retirement home uninhabitable.  The storm separated the back wall from the home, ripped up the roof in several places, and drenched everything inside.  ‚ÄúIt blew in with such a powerful suction that everything got wet‚Ä¶ anything that was in here was damaged. They had to totally gut it,‚Äù McBride showed ABC Action News.  WFTS  McBrides  McBrides  Nearly eight months later, the couple said they‚Äôve only received enough money from their insurance company, American Integrity, to replace the roof and a temporary back wall.  Even after hiring a public adjuster for help with their claim, they said they‚Äôre still pleading with their insurance to help make their home livable.  ‚ÄúWe went to these contractors and they gave us estimates ‚Äî all in the same ballpark of what it's going to take to rebuild our house and when we had our mediation with our carrier, they wanted to pay pennies on the dollar,‚Äù McBride expressed. ‚ÄúWe could never; we're not rich; we could never rebuild our house like it was before.‚Äù  McBride said most estimates are around $220,000, and the cost of supplies is only going up the longer they wait.  According to the McBride‚Äôs claims documents, the insurance adjuster estimated about $40,000 in damages.  With their $5,500 deductible, the couple and their public adjuster received a check for $35,000 in November.  The McBrides have also been paying rent to live elsewhere for the last seven months. According to their policy, their insurance covers ‚Äúloss of use‚Äù up to $27,000, which would include having to pay rent, but the company marked the loss of use value at zero.  In contrast, the couple‚Äôs public adjuster‚Äôs estimate calculates replacement costs at $224,000, with at least $36,000 for loss of use.  ‚ÄúWe're defeated and it's just like, what are we going to do?‚Äù McBride said emotionally, ‚ÄúWe're gonna have to take our claim to court because they leave us no choice.‚Äù  The Insurance Information Institute estimates insurance companies will pay $10-$20 billion to Ian-related litigation, in turn contributing to more financial burden and higher premiums for homeowners across the state.  ‚ÄúYou can't settle it for literally 20 cents on the dollar‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs not fair,‚Äù explained the McBride‚Äôs public adjuster Jerry Daniels with Corbitt Public Adjusting.  Daniels said their company currently has hundreds of Ian victims, with only less than 10% of claims closed. He said many clients came to them in December and January when the 90-day state requirement for insurance companies to pay claims ended, and people received checks far below what they needed.  ‚ÄúThe path that we have to take is completely contingent upon the decisions they make. If they were willing to come to the table and be reasonable, we could settle these,‚Äù Daniels explained.  We reached out to American Integrity asking about the McBride‚Äôs claim. A spokesperson said they can‚Äôt ‚Äúcomment on a claim with attorney and/or public adjuster representation.‚Äù  ‚ÄúI want my home back. I want to get up and make coffee in my own coffee pot, and I want to bring groceries back here and cook it and put on the table for my husband,‚Äù McBride expressed. ‚ÄúThings I always enjoyed doing. It's all taken away from me, and how much longer?‚Äù  WFTS  According to the state‚Äôs reporting data, the McBride‚Äôs claim is one of nearly 110,000 Ian claims still open as of March.  We reached out to the Florida Office of Insurance Regulation (OIR) to ask about the concerns of insurance companies underpaying policies.  A spokesperson for OIR said they are aware of ‚Äúaccusations claiming insurance companies are not fulfilling their obligations to pay out claims.‚Äù They confirm they are investigating company claims-handling for Hurricane Ian and are ‚Äúcommitted to protecting Floridians in this recovery process.‚Äù  We also followed up with the American Policyholder Association (APA). In December, APA Executive Director Doug Quinn said they were already fielding complaints regarding insurance companies. Now he confirms they are specifically recording complaints from those working within the industry.  "Since the APA focuses on criminal fraud perpetrated by the insurance industry against consumers, we‚Äôre not keeping stats on complaints from consumers related to insurer bad faith, but we have received quite a few," Quinn responded.  "The complaints we have been focusing on are related to insurance industry insiders who have come forward with complaints of potential fraud perpetrated to underpay Florida policyholders on their claims. To date, over 30 insurance insiders have reached out, although most wish to remain behind the scenes due to fear of retaliation by the insurance industry," he said.  One thing to keep in mind regarding any legal action as a result of Hurricane Ian is that new laws stopping fee multipliers do not apply.  Last year‚Äôs second legislative special session addressing Florida‚Äôs property insurance crisis took place two months after Hurricane Ian hit. This means that insurance companies still have to pay their policyholder's attorney fees if they‚Äôre taken to court and found liable for more damages; this can be up a rate up to $800 an hour.  Insurance companies that have gone insolvent or pulled out of the state in recent years have claimed financial burden from this type of "runaway litigation."  According to the Office Of Insurance Regulation, 79,220 lawsuits were filed against insurance companies in 2020, with underwriting losses of more than a billion dollars.  Going forward, carriers won‚Äôt have to pay these fees, but public adjusters say this is also worrisome because many homeowners won‚Äôt be able to afford help if their claims are denied or underpaid by insurance companies in instances like a hurricane.  American Integrity is one of the largest domestic property insurers in Florida. The company's CEO, Bob Ritchie, spoke to ABC Action News In-Depth Reporter Stassy Olmos about the property insurance crisis one year ago this month.  In an interview, he told Olmos that it had been a seven-year battle to sort through the roof storm damage claims coming in by more than two-dozen daily.  ‚ÄúWe have 250 employees; our largest department by staffing and payroll is our legal department,‚Äù Ritchie explained. ‚ÄúOf course, there are valid claims. We do our discovery, our adjudication, and some, in fact, are covered,‚Äù he said regarding roofing scams.  Here is the full statement from OIR regarding their actions post Hurricane Ian:  ‚ÄúOIR is aware of the accusations claiming insurance companies are not fulfilling their obligations to pay out claims to policyholders. Below is some additional information regarding OIR‚Äôs role in the claims-handling process, which may be helpful to your viewers.  OIR encourages consumers who having issues with a claim to report it. OIR works closely with the Dept. of Financial Services (DFS) Division of Consumer Services and Insurance Consumer Advocate to receive claims data and review consumer issues. OIR continues to review claims and complaint data from all stakeholders to evaluate insurers and remains committed to protecting Floridians in this recovery process. OIR is conducting investigations into company claims handling for Hurricane Ian. These investigations are confidential and exempt from public records until the investigation is completed or ceases to be active, per s. 624.319(3)(a)2., F.S.  Following Hurricane Ian, OIR issued numerous data calls to track market impacts and initiated more than 50 market conduction investigations to evaluate aspects of the claims handling process. Based on the findings of an examination or investigation, OIR‚Äôs market regulation units may take administrative action, impose administrative penalties, and require corrective action in order to protect insurance consumers from unlawful or harmful business practices.  It‚Äôs important to note, that while OIR is conducting investigations into company claims handling for Hurricane Ian, OIR‚Äôs market regulation units monitor and enforce insurer and insurance-related entity compliance with the Florida Insurance Code. When conducting an examination or investigation, OIR‚Äôs market regulation units take a comprehensive review of all business practices to identify issues such as form compliance, claims handling, insurer communication, proper claims investigation, interest paid on overdue claims, adequate monitoring of third-party administrators and managing general agents, and claims settlements. During these examinations or investigations, OIR‚Äôs market regulation units review all applicable information and documentation to identify and resolve alleged violations of Florida law.  I would also note, Governor DeSantis and the Florida Legislature have passed a number of consumer protections as part of the recent insurance reforms, including expediting the claims and communication process and providing OIR with explicit market conduct authority. As a result, OIR will not only be reviewing how insurers are responding to claims subject to previous prompt payment timeframes, but how they plan to update their processes to accommodate shortened timeframes.‚Äù  Click here to read about the Hurricane Ian insurance crisis specifically for homeowners with United Property & Casualty.
